text:
I'm changing my rating to a 2 star.  I hadn't made these cookies in a while, and I forgot about my notes in my first review below.  I didn't add the extra flour and baking powder this last time and this cookies ran like crazy!  I now understand why some where so disappointed. The extra flour REALLY makes the difference.  Without this alteration, the original recipe is not good.
Hope this helps!
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In an attempt to make "perfect" cookies the first try, I read many of the reviews here.  Guess what!  It worked!  These cookies are fantastic.  I did soak the raisins by putting them in a colander, placing the colander in a saucepan and running hot tap water over them enough to cover them.  I let them soak while preparing the dough.  Another concern expressed in other reviews was that these cookies came out flat and ran into each other.  To try and avoid this happening, I used 1/4 cup more flour and added 1/2 tsp. baking powder.  These did not run at all, and are slightly poofy.

text:
This is a great recipe! I've read most reviews about the recipe and the most common concerns seem to be that the cookie spreads too thinly when baked and that it is too sweet or bland. I have cut down the sugar to 1/2 cup each of brown and white sugar and added 1/4 tsp ground cloves and 1/4 tsp of ground allspice. Also feel free to add more cinnamon if you like. This made the cookies very flavorful. The trick  is, however, mixing the dough by HAND and NOT overworking it. Follow the recipe and incorporate the dry ingredients into the wet in three stages. Do not use a mixer or you will overwork the dough and get flat cookies. I have also soaked the raisins in hot water and drained them in a sieve prior to adding them at the end. Bake the cookies on a cookie sheet at 350 or lower depending on your oven (I baked mine at 325 because my oven was too hot). Regardless at which temperature you bake them, make sure you keep an eye on them after 5-8 minutes and take them out when the edges are golden brown. I had no problems baking these or removing them from the pan. They are moist, flavorful, and delicious. Thanks for a great recipe! This one's a keeper.

text:
for those folks who had issues with the cookies sticking to the pan, etc...since these cookies are made with butter, you need to use a non-insulated shiny cookie sheet.  This will allow the whole cookie to bake without the butter melting first and the cookie turning out flat and crunchy.  (If you substitute shortening for the butter, you can use an insulated pan without a problem, too.)

text:
Delicious cookie.  I tweaked it slightly, though; I used more raisins and soaked them in boiling water first (they were moister and plumper this way), I added a bit more cinnamon, and the batter seemed wet so I ended up adding more flour and oats.  However, I would not recommend adding more oats; it was too overpowering.  I decided to make monster cookies, hoping they would turn our big and chewy, which they did.  I got 20 large cookies from this recipe.  Watch the baking time carefully, only adding a minute at a time, if you want chewy cookies.

text:
Tried and true my foot. My boyfriend had a craving for oatmeal cookies last weekend, so I wanted to make him a treat. These were the worst cookies I've ever made. I consider myself a pretty good cook. When I read the reviews, a couple people said that it didn't work for them. My boyfriend and I assumed these people must not have been following the recipe correctly. These cookies had the worst consistency ever. They hardened up into flat discs as soon as I took them out of them oven. Somehow they stuck to my non-stick, commercial baking pan, even when it was greased. I had to chisel them off (and clean the pan between batches). When I put even a teaspoon of dough out for each cookie, they would spread flat and the raisins would burn. I even tried freezing the dough for the last batch. After about an hour out of the oven the consistency would turn flimsy and sticky. I wish I took a picture to submit. After three batches, all the cookies went into the trash. What a waste of time. It angered both my boyfriend and myself. This recipe either needs to be rewritten or taken out of the tried and true section. I took the leftover dough and added baking powder, another egg, more flour, more oats, applesauce and some spices (poppy seeds, orange peel, vanilla, and coconut). I put the dough in muffin tins and made great muffins. if you have the same problems I had, you might want to try this. The extra ingredients help the dough stay together and rise.

text:
This recipe came out perfectly for me the first time I tried it. They are a hit with my family. I read most of the reviews here prior to starting. I did soak my raisins which made them extra plump, but I found I did not need to add the extra flour or baking soda, as the dough already had a nice consistency. My cookies did not run at all, and puffed up quite nicely. I cut the white sugar down to 1/2 cup, but kept the brown sugar at 3/4 cup. This did not affect the taste of the cookies, thanks to the raisins, which add natural sweetness. I also added a little extra cinnamon as well as ground star anise (1/2 tsp) to this recipe, which gives a nice flavour. For baking, I rolled spoon-sized amounts of the dough into balls. I turned my oven down to 350, as I found the first batch to be browning a little too quickly on the edges. My cookies needed about 9 minutes, but I had to watch them. They aren't the kind that you can pop in the oven and walk away.  Here's a tip: if you want a slightly flatter cookie, press the cookies down with a fork about 1/2 through baking.

I will definitely be making these again!

Really good cookies! I cut the white sugar down to 1/2 cup, bumped cinnamon up to a whole teaspoon, and added 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg. If you are having problems with them sticking, it is because you have to let them cool a little on the sheet pan. I used a baking spray and they came off easily for me.

This was a very tasty recipe, exactly what I was looking for.  It's hard to find an oatmeal raisin cookie recipe that uses butter instead of shortening.  I was a little leary before making it because some people said the cookies turned out hard, but I have just finished baking them and they turned out perfectly moist.  Maybe others baked them too long.  Make sure you don't overbake if you want them moist, maybe even take them out a couple minutes early.  Great recipe, thanks!

text:
An exceptionally good recipe. No, it doesn't need extra flour as a few dissenters insist.  That might make them thicker and maybe softer, but they would lose their chewiness. If your not after a nice chewy cookie, find another one to make. I hope I speak for the hundreds and hundreds of us that had no problems and loved these cookies when I say to the small handfull who struggled and then went on in bitter rants about how it must be a bad recipe, "Its not us, its you."  There are a thousand things that can affect a recipe turning out right from atmospheric conditions to the type of ingredients used to the skill of the person making the food and sometimes we all experience something not turning out right.  My experience was this: the cookies are fabulous.

text:
Nothing to change, nothing to criticize.  I prepared the recipe just as directed and was very pleased. I did, however, use chocolate covered raisins which made these extra gooey and good. And, as I always do with cookie doughs made with butter, I refrigerated the dough for about an hour until it firmed up a little. I used a tablespoon-sized cookie scoop and flattened them just slightly. They're soft and chewy, but still a little crispy along the edges. Everything you'd want in this type of cookie.

Wow....lots of reviews on these cookies and quite a bit that were negative...and I do not understand why so many people can have such vastly different results.  I followed the recipe to the letter and my cookies turned out PERFECT! Chewy, slightly poofy, the dough did not run or spread and I always, always, ALWAYS bake cookies on parchment lined cookie sheets - NO sticking and you don't need to grease them therfore adding extra grease of which I think is the major culprit for cookies that spread to much.  This recipe is fabulous as written, someone else suggested putting allspice or nutmeg in, which would definitely enhance that 'spiced' cookie flavour, but if you want just an oatmeal raisin cookie - then this is it! Thanks for the great recipe! Hubby and I hoovered 4 each after they came out of the oven! :)

text:
I haven't ever really learned to bake since my mixer caught fire in my hands the first time I used it hah (traumatic experience, trust me!). But I figured I"d try baking this year for Christmas. Hubby doesn't like chocolate, and I don't like raisins, so I used dried cranberries instead. I read the reviews, and added 1/4 cup flour and 1/2 tsp baking soda because we like soft cookies. I also used 1/2 cup of butter and 1/4 cup butter flavored shortening. Also made it a full 1 tsp of cinnamon. I just pulled the last cookie sheet out and they are AWESOME. With those changes, I will definitely make this again using the dried cranberries instead.

text:
Remember that ingredients, especially flour, vary a lot in how much moisture ther contain by geographic location.  I'm in Denver, and flour etc is very dry.  I've made this recipe twice: once increasing the flour by 50% as recommended, and once as printed here.  The result was *much* better following the recipe here.  So, before you are overly critical, consider that maybe your location requires a modification that does not apply to all bakers.

text:
Just took the 1st batch out of the oven....and  ohhhhhhhhhh man...they are GOOD! I love oatmeal raisin cookies, but for some reason, never made them before. I used large flaked oatmeal and Thompsons raisins for my ingredients. The only thing I tweaked was the amount of salt. I always find that oatmeal raisin cookies are salty, so I only did a shake of my salt shaker, as I thought the recipe called for waaay too much. Baked for 8 mins, and they are perfect. Thanks so much for the great recipe!!!!!  ----------------  * little side note. I just read through some of the other reviews and noticed that there were complaints of the cookie falling apart/being too soft/runny...I noticed that they were soft too, coming right out of the oven....I left them on the baking sheet without touching them for 3-4 minutes. They firmed up nicely enough to transfer to the wire rack, and finished cooling there. If you read whole recipe directions, it will tell you to do the same!

userID:
14317226
Display Name:
kitkatK
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were great!  After reading a ton of good, bad and iffy reviews, I was a bit nervous to make 'as is', but I'm glad I did.. well, mostly. :)

Things I changed: increased the cinnamon to 1 tsp, added a couple of dashes of nutmeg and clove, threw in a small palmful of ground (in my coffee grinder) raw flaxseed and chia seed (as I am making these to be a good snack for my kids and wanted to give them an extra BUMP).

Comments:

People who's cookies ran together- were you ovens at 375?  At 350, the butter is going to melt faster than the cookie can bake, therefore making it run.  I had zero problems with my cookies crisping up too fast at 375, and I have a crappy oven, lol.

People's who's cookies fell apart, crumbled and stuck.  You have to let and cool and I mean COOL.  As much as you want to, you have to let it be and 'set up' or yes, it will fall apart and stick.

I did not soak my raisins and they were fine.  Baking in the oven for 8-10 minutes plumped them up enough.

I used old fashioned rolled oats, not quick oats. Not sure if that made a difference in the runny cookies, but mine are just like a normal cookie consistancy.. a little thick, bumpy, chewy, buttery cookie.. delicious!  

I will definitely make these again, and am thinking up a good 9x13 casserole recipe for them as a bar.  

Thanks!

text:
I'm not exactly a cooking expert but I know a few things here and there. This has to be the coolest and easiest recipe I've had the pleasure to use. My trick for the way they came out is the butter. SOFT BUTTER!! SOFT! SOFT! SOFT! ALSO,  I mixed the key ingredients using a blender then I used a spoon to mix in the rest. Over mixing can happen and it makes the cookies flat. using a shiny pan helps prevent burning.  I sent these to my husband out in Iraq and he loved them!  THANKS AGAIN! :) P.S. I'm looking for the perfect Chocolate Chip Cookie recipe... anyone??

I was so excited to make these and saw that it had a great rating. text:
I think I know what happened with people getting runny cookies. I just made this recipe twice: once with quick-cooking oats, and once with old fashioned rolled oats. The ones with the quick oats were extremely thick and cakey (great if that's the kind of cookie you prefer), and the ones with the old fashioned oats spread all over the cookie sheet, and were a delicious something, but not really cookies. 

Perhaps if the original recipe were revised to say quick-cooking oats, it would help people get the results they want (also, smash the cookies out flat before baking because they won't spread at all with the quick oats).

text:
My husband loves oatmal raisin cookies (his absolute favorite) so I wanted to make them homemade for him. I halved the entire recipe (since he's the only one who eats them), added 2 extra tablespoons of flour, soaked the raisins in hot water to plump them up, and used old-fashioned oats instead (couldn't find rolled oats at the supermarket). The cookies didn't run together and plumped up nicely. Outside was crispy, yet the inside was chewy. My hubby loved them, so the recipe will definitely go into the recipe box!

text:
An absolutely perfect recipe with a few alterations. I took the advice from other reviews and cut the white sugar down to 1/2 cup, added 1/4 cup flour, changed amout of cinnamon to 1 tsp, added 1/4 tsp nutmeg, and soaked the raisins in boiling water before adding to the rest of the batter. 
Also, I baked the cookies at 350 degrees for 6 minutes, rotated the baking sheet and baked for another 3 minutes. They looked slightly underdon when I took them out of the oven (brown around edges, but shiny in center) so I let them cool on the baking sheet and they finished cooking this way.
Absolutely perfect!

Great recipe! One point of advice though....slightly beat your eggs and combine with the raisins, before making the cookies -- let stand for 15-20 minutes...then combine egg (along with raisins) as recipe calls for. For best results, let raisins and eggs stand in your refrigerator 45 mins to 1 hour before making cookies, and you'll have amazing results!

text:
I judge a recipe based on how it's written and not by how I altered it.  I tried this recipe EXACTLY as it's written.  My "cookies" turned into flat discs of oatmeal and raisins. They litterally flattened out into a big sheet of cookie on the baking sheet.  Thankfully, my 4 year old doesn't care as long as there is sugar in it.  The flavor was there, but I'll never make them as written again.   

After the first two dozen turned out like an oatmeal raisin waffle cone, I added another 1/4 cup of flour and about 1/2 tsp of baking powder to the remaining dough. They actually held a cookie consistency after that.

country:
None
text:
These are the best oatmeal cookies I've ever eaten or made. I followed the core recipe exactly until the very end. I split the dough in two before adding raisins. I added 1/2 cup of raisins to one half of the dough. I added 1/2 cup of sweetened dried cranberries to the other half plus 2 tablespoons of unsweetened cocoa powder. Then I chilled both doughs in the freezer for about 15-20 minutes before baking. I made sure to grease the baking sheet. No issues with sticking to the sheet or running. The end result was two delicious cookies from one easy to follow recipe. Yummy! Chilling the dough keeps the cookies from running and it doesn't affect the integrity of the dough or the flavor.

text:
The Oatmeal Raisin Cookies I is one of the best oatmeal cookie recipes that I have made and would rate as 5 stars had the flour amount was correct.  I agree with one reviewer about the flour amount should have been 1-1/2 cups instead of 1-1/4.  Too little flour makes the cookie too soft to keep its shape, especially if you like a moist, chewier oatmeal cookie.  Watch your baking time, because the flavor and the moist texture is best when it is not over baked.

text:
I have been making these cookies for over a year, and they are always well received.  Initially, they were not chewy enough for my liking, so I made the following adjustments over time. -- Increase butter to 1 cup.  Replace 1/4 cup of white sugar with brown sugar.  Increase raisins to 1-1/2 cups. -- I also increase cinnamon to 1/2 TBSP and dust the unbaked cookies with cinnamon sugar.  Bake on insulated baking sheets to keep the bottoms from burning, and enjoy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe. I have baked these several times, and I always double the recipe.  I do not drop them however, instead I roll them into small balls and place them on a baking tray lined with Baking paper. They have never run, or have I had burned butter in them. They all come out perfect and I make them perhaps too small but they fit nicely into the small chubby hands of my Toddler.  The cookies do not flatten out to much but have a nice thick, chewy middle. I use California Sunmade Raisins and have never needed to soften them. I made them last summer for a family get together, and no one believed that I baked them as they were all relatively the same shape, size and too perfect to be made by hand!  One tip, when I am rolling them out, I have a small bowl of cold water, that I dip my fingers into so that the dough does not stick to my hands. When two trays are in the oven, I pre-roll for the next batch and line them up on another sheet of baking paper, so I can quickly return the baking sheets to the oven.

country:

text:
I read the reviews for this recipe and I adjusted it based on what everyones comments were.  I definitely wanted to avoid a "way too sugary" cookie so I reduced both sugars to 1/2 cup each.  I also took reviewers' advice and added 1/3 teaspoon of nutmeg and I doubled the cinnamon and the cookies are just perfect...taste wise.  I could not have even imagined how bland they would have been without the additional spices.  Soaking the raisins for 10 minutes in hot water was a great tip, they were so plump and juicy!  The down side to my cookies is that I listened to everyone when they said that they were coming out flat and crispy.  Because of this, I added 1/2 teaspoon of baking powder and my dough came out super stiff, almost too stiff and they barely spread at all.  They came out more something you would have for breakfast rather than dessert.  Next time I will follow the recipe exactly.

text:
terrific cookies! some of those complaining might have used margarine instead of butter. that will affect the consistency of your dough. the sticking to your pan complaint has more to do with your preparation than the actual recipe. i used my pampered chef stones and all was perfect. when i removed them from the oven, they seemed to be "not quite done"; i could see a bit of dough in the center. but waiting a few minutes for them to set up was the trick! taking them out of the oven at the right time prevents them from becoming too hard. my oven at 375 worked perfectly. i agree with the poster who said let them cool slightly before transferring them to cooling rack. i got 36 medium-sized cookies. oatmeal raisin is my husband's favorite, and this recipe has just moved to the front of my recipe box!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the greatest recipe for oatmeal cookies ever. My family can't get enough. However, there are three things that I have found make them turn out better and prettier.

The first is use parchment paper. This recipe tends to run and flaten. If you use parchment paper and mound your dough, you will get nice cookie shaped cookies. 

The next thing is, only the bottoms should be brown if you want a cookie that tastes great and is moist right out of the oven and tomorrow, too. 

The third is this recipe needs room in the mixing bowl. Use the largest you have or use a fruit bowl or salad bowl for mixing. It can get heavy and sticky quickly and you will need room to make sure that all the ingredients get well blended. (but not over blended)

text:
I just whipped these cookies up as a Sunday afternoon whim and they are very yummy!  I am new to the world of baking so I LOVE easy and successful recipes and this one is both!
I noticed a few reviews said that the dough ran and to not use a mixer but to hand mix.  I used my KitchenAid, with the dough hook for the flour mixing, and my cookies did not run at all.
First off I only made a 1/2 batch (2 dozen).  I used craisins instead of raisins and I soaked them in hot water while prepping the dough.  I did cut back the white sugar by about 1/4C and I added Nutmeg.
They are sweet and tasty without feeling heavy.  I won't feel guilty when I binge eat the babies!  :)

Just added one more item to this recipe and that was M&M's (the peanut ones), and boy Oh boy did they ever turn out perfect! Just look at my pic of them, I got 34 good size cookies out of this recipe, and yes, I followed what other users said and that is to soak your rasins in a bowl of water for at least 30 min. prior to mixing and boy do you ever have a super moist cookie with rasins & M&M's :)  Just mix in the M&M's with the rasins, the end result is you have a fiber moist/crunchy rich cookie.  Fiber is important in today's diet and just look at all the cookies you get from this recipe, at least 30-36 good size cookies. Enjoy!!!! See my pic with rasins & M&M's

None
text:
I love this recipe!  I always get compliments on these cookies.  I, like many other people, soak the raisins in hot water for at least 20 minutes prior to adding them into the batter so their nice and plump.  If your cookies are coming out flat as pancakes, your butter is too warm.  Don't melt it in the microwave and then throw it in your mixer.  Bad idea.  Let your butter get soft on our counter OR rotate turn the stick of butter on a different side every 4 seconds for 4 total rotations (sometimes it's a little less time depending on the microwave).

text:
I'm sure the US version of this recipe works perfectly and is lovely, but when you translate it to metric, the quantities go all wrong. The US one calls for 1.5 cups of sugar total and 1.25 cups of flour. In the metric one it tells you to use more than twice as much sugar as you do flour. I don't know if this is human error or your conversion system is just atrocious, but it's responsible for all the runny cookies.

text:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE this recipe, AS WRITTEN. I read some of the negative reviews and I think they are written by people who prefer a more fluffy, cakey cookie like those you would find in a pepperidge farm bag. Myself, I like my cookies chewy in the center with a little carmelization crunch on the edge. They did spread quite a bit, but I would liken the effect to a typical chocolate chip cookie. My husband loved the cookies too, and I will be making them again for certain. And I definitely won't be adding extra flour to this recipe, as I fear it would throw off the delicate balance between chewy and crunchy this cookie has going on.

Mrs. Powell

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my official go-to recipe for oatmeal raisin cookies.  I have now made it twice, once with butter-flavor shortening, and once with real butter, and I definitely prefer the butter version.  I did follow the suggestions of other reviewers and added 1/4 cup more of flour, 1/2 tsp of baking powder, and a 1/4 tsp of nutmeg.  If you use the butter-flavor shortening, do not increase the flour; the cookies will not flatten.  I always bake cookies on parchment paper, so there is no issue of sticking.  Most importantly, soak your raisins in a strainer in a bowl of boiling hot while you make the dough; it makes the raisins super plump and juicy.  I make these and immediately bag them up for friends and coworkers; otherwise, I'll eat the entire batch!  :)
Review:

city:

country:
None
text:
These were AWESOME and just what the doctor ordered, to satisfy my craving. =D I was a little unsure of the recipe 'coz a couple of the 'most helpful' reviews, tore this recipe to shreds. Hence, I halved the quantity and made only 24, which I heartily regret. I made a few tweaks (although nothing earth shattering). I used dried currants instead of raisins (coz I realised I didn't have raisins only after I'd started making this =P ), and added a bit of ground cloves and allspice to the flour mixture. Also, sine I'd halved this, this called ofr a little over 1/4 cup of brown sugar and whi sugar, so I used the brown sugar and added jut a tablespoon of white sugar to it. It was easily sweet enough and definitely healthier. =) I baked these at about 180degrees and they took 12 minutes to reach my preferred chewy state. Oh and as suggested by many reviewers, I soaked the currants in hot water whilst preparing the rest of the batter of the cookie. Thanks alot for sharing Darlene. This is definitely a keeper! =)

country:

text:
I would give this recipe 5 stars with some simple changes I made, some suggested by other reviewers.   I boiled the raisins in water and let them soak for a few minutes. This made them plump and moist! For spices, I did 1 tsp. Cinnamon, a dash of Nutmeg, and 1 tsp. Allspice. I also added a Cup or so of chocolate chips, along with the raisins, and really enjoy the cookies that way.    These turned out AMAZING! The best oatmeal raisin cookie I've ever eaten! Make sure you take them out of the oven soon enough. Just when they start to brown on the edges. They may still look a little too soft on top, like they need more baking, but they will settle quickly and be nice and chewy while not underdone! Mine took ten minutes, but that's just my oven... Enjoy!

text:
As always, I followed the recipe exactly as written, so I could give a true review. Mine turned out great! They were VERY moist and chewy and yummy. I only got 24, but used TBS instead of dropping TSP on the cookie sheet. I used parchment paper, and they pulled off easily. I guess since I dropped TBS instead of TSP, my cookies were puffy and gorgeous.

August 2012 - made these again and only changed things by adding extra half cup of flour. OMGoodness, they were AWESOME! Used parchment paper, chilled dough while pan was cooking, and baked for 11 minutes..that was the best time for my oven. This recipe rocks and I upped my stars!

text:
I rate this a four with modifications, a three without. I did a first batch exactly as the recipe and what I got was more like oatmeal lace cookies. I didn't *not* like them, but wasn't expecting that consistency. So then I did a second batch, added 1/4 cup flour, scooped 1 and 1/2 t dough for each cookie, (about 28 cookies) baked for 9 minutes convection-bake and removed them from the pan to a cooling rack immediately. And they came out great.

With changes others have mentioned it's a 5 star: Up the flour to 1 1/2 cups, reduce the white sugar to 1/2 cup, pre-soak the raisins, add 1/2 tsp baking powder.  I noticed that the cookies I made towards the end of the bowl (after dough sat for about 25 minutes) were considerably less spread out than the others. Next time I'll let the dough sit for a while before baking the first trays. The flat ones are plenty tasty, but would prefer the rounder ones.

Really nice cookie but a little too sweet for me. I am not a tremendous oatmeal raisin cookie but my boyfriend happens to be so I am always in search of a good recipe. I soaked the raisins in a some hot water for about 15 minutes to make them plump and softer. Put in some chopped pecans for added texture.  I did put the dough in the fridge for about 30 minutes and I think that did the trick to make the dough firmer and not run while baking. Also used whole wheat flour because that was all that I had. Will make them again.

You know, I love a good oatmeal raisin cookie.  However, I was out of raisins and substituted orange-essence dried cranberries, and I may never go back!  They were just absolutely delicious.  This is a softer cookie - not a crisp cookie.  I like both kinds, depending on my mood.  I also liked the size of this batch - about 24 good sized cookies, so not so many that they'll go bad before we can eat them.  Very yummy iced with cream cheese frosting, still warm with a glass of ice cold milk.  I substituted all of the regular granulated sugar with Splenda, and it didn't hurt the appeal at all!

text:
I really like this recipe, to me it is very simple and basic. In other words you can modify as you like without harming the cookie. For instance Iwanted to make it as healthy as possible,considering that it is a cookie! So I divided the butter and used Coconut Oil as the other half. I added about 1/4 cup of coconut milk and then added about 1/2 cup of freshly ground flax seed meal and about 1/4 C. Pecan fines because I am trying to use up what I have on hand, (poor teeth, really)I also had about two handfuls of carob chips, so add 1 hanful.Then I found that the cooking time was a bit short for my additions so I lowered the temp to 350 and extended the time to 15 to 18 min. I just don't think that there is any way you could harm these cookies. Of, course listen to the other reviews and get them off the baking sheet immediately, then enjoy. What a cool recipe. btw I two soaked the raisins a bit but don't think it too necessary deepending on the condition of the raisins, if pretty dry then by all means soak. Ginny

text:
They were too sweet, not very flavourful, and stuck to the pan the first time I made them, so I made some changes to the recipe for the next batch. I reduced the white sugar to 1/3 cup and the butter to 5/8 cup, added 2 tablespoons of real maple syrup, omitted the vanilla, and doubled the amount of cinnamon. I also greased the baking pan well and baked the cookies at 350 degrees instead of 375. They came out wonderful!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe very closely, and had the same problem that a few others did--the very flat cookie that was near impossible to get off the pan.  I tried refrigerating the dough, turning down the heat, greasing the pan, using a different cookie sheet, making larger cookies...none of these helped much.  I found that if I just scraped the cookies off the pan as fast as I could once out of the oven, I didn't have such a problem with the pan being encrusted with crunchy cookie residue.  Once these cookies were cooled a bit on the rack, they were delicious.  I like thicker cookies, but these still managed to be chewy in the center, though crunchy around the edges, and the flavor was good despite being *slightly* too sweet.

text:
Recipe as is is flatter than a pancake, looked more like lace with airholes than a cookie. Finally got a good cookie by adding enough flour to have a stiff dough, chilled dough baked at 375. Here are all the things I tried first: Let cool a little then tried to get off pan, fell apart, so mushed it together, discovered it makes a nice oatmeal raisin popcorn like ball (walnut size) so did the same to each of the baked cookies.  Rescued my first pan efforts and ingredients, the cookie ball tastes great:)  Next tried putting in fridge to chill, dough still baked the same. Reduced heat to 350 same result. Added more flour to remaining dough, baked on air sheet and also on regular cookie sheet still not enough flour added a bunch more ... GOT A COOKIE!!!

I noticed many previous postings added extra flour and Baking soda. I Think the Reason some of the previous posts had thinning and Sticking and burning issues was I believe was because the amount dropped  per cookie the recipe calls for a teaspoon per cookie I used a Rounded  TABLESPOON  size drop per cookie.I consulted another tried and true Oatmeal Cookie recipe on the Oatmeal Box it recommended the Tablespoon Sized drop per cookie this made for a  Big Flavorful Moist and Chewy  with NO BURNT BOTTOMS even without parchment paper or greasing the cookie sheet or cooking spray or Extra Flour and Baking Soda this Recipe turned out to taste pretty close to the Cookie I remember my Mom making as a Kid

These cookies are awesome just as the recipe reads.  I have made this recipe more then  30 times, and people always say they are the best oatmeal cookies they ever tasted.  I think the problem with other reviews saying the batter is runny, is they are making the butter too soft to start with.  That will give you runny batter.  I follow the recipe, but I don't measure the cinnamon, so I know there is more then 3/4 teaspoon in there. I add chocolate chips and raisins, and they are perfect!

text:
I love these cookies! My Mom used to make these exact cookies for me when I was a child, but we had lost the recipe. When I found this recipe I ate the whole batch in one night! I honestly cannot make this recipe and keep them all for myself because I will eat them all. I usually make them when I am going to visit family so I don't eat them all. My family adores these. They spread quite a bit when baking so they make really large cookies. I don't find that they are too thin, because of their size it kind of evens out. I bake them just until cooked so they stay soft and moist. I am a total cinnamon lover though, so I do add extra (instead of  3/4 tsp I use a heaped teaspoon, I always add extra cinnamon in any recipe). I don't find them bland at all. They are such a classic recipe. I honestly wouldn't add nutmeg or anything because this is a simple oatmeal raisin cookie and taste like a classic cookie. A word of warning: once you try these you will crave them, they will change your life!

I actually modified this recipe so it would be gluten free. I made it with about 1.25 cups almond flour, 1/8 cup ground flax meal, 1/8 cup corn starch, 1 tsp xantham gum. I also had to increase the oatmeal to 3 cups so the cookie dough had the right consistency. Delicious!

text:
Okay I know I'm not the first person to say this judging from all the wonderful reviews, but these cookies are great! So my first try in making these, they did in fact turn into flat UFO disks. I followed the recipe exactly how it said and I could taste that the flavor was there, but the puffiness was completely missing. Yesterday, I had  craving for them and decided to give another whack at it. I used the advice from another fellow reviewer by cutting out some of the sugar (just half a cup of each), turning down my oven temp, and making sure to mix everything by HAND until it was just incorporated. Trust me, it made all the difference. They turned out chewy and delicious and (most importantly) PUFFY! I also added some walnuts to the mix this time and sprayed my pans really well with cooking spray to avoid sticking. Don't give in after the first try!

text:
I made these yesterday and they were a huge hit, BUT after reading some reviews I did not stick to the original recipe so I can't really rate the recipe as it is exactly. 
The changes I made are: I used an extra 1/4 cup flour (1 1/2 cup total); used shortening instead of butter (equal amount); doubled the vanilla (we're vanilla fans); added 1/4 tsp nutmeg; added 1 tsp pumpkin pie spice (this gave them a nice subtle pumpkiny flavor, if you're into that). Also, while I was preparing the dough, the raisins were plumping in a bowl of hot water (with more vanilla) and they were so moist and yummy in the finished product. Adding walnuts would have been fantastic, but I didn't have any on hand and will definitely try next time.

I was skeptical at first reading all the negative comments on this recipe. However, I tried and just finished baking the first batch of these cookies and wow, these are really really good! I followed everything according to the recipes but when I shaped the cookies dough I did open the window to let the cool air in and keep the dough from melting too fast in the oven. The cookies came out nicely - no flat shapes whatsoever. The dough came out a bit soft at first so I left them on the baking sheet for a while before transferring them to the cooling rack. I will definitely bake them again!

text:
These were so good I immediately threw away all of my other oatmeal raisin cookie recipes. Yes, it's that good. After reading the reviews I made the following adjustments: I soaked the raisins in hot water while I made the dough, I added 1/4 cup of flour, and 1/4 tsp baking powder, I left them on the cookie sheet for a couple of minutes before removing them to cooling racks. Cookie nirvana achieved. Perfect seasoning, lightly chewy, awesome recipe!

text:
This recipe did not turn out well for me.  Here is what I did:
I followed recipe exactly except I doubled the vanilla extract and cinnamon.  I initially creamed the butter and sugars by hand, but that didn't work so well, so I switched to a hand mixer. When it was time to mix in the flour mixture, I did that by hand, gradually pouring in a little at a time.  I then placed the batter in the freezer for about 18 minutes.  I did not waste anytime and then scooped out medium size balls onto a parchment lined baking sheet.  I then baked the cookies in a 350-degree oven (I felt 375 was too hot), checking after 5 minutes.  After the first 5 minutes, the cookies had spread quite a bit, but they were no where near done in the middle.  So I baked them for 3 minutes longer and they were done, but flat as pancakes.  I was so disappointed.  I tasted them and thought they tasted good, but I'm giving this recipe one star because the shape of the cookies were just awful.  I will not be making this recipe again.

text:
Oatmeal Raisin Cookies I' Haiku: "Wavered on 3 stars. No fault of the recipe, I followed reviews." Blurgh, so I read loads of reviews, and reduced the sugars and the temperature, and first batch was smoosh, smoosh, batter smoosh, then Blammo, one minute later they're burned. So I tried the recipe's 8-10 min. at 375 deg. instructions, and had to crouch by the oven and guard-dog the last batches to ensure that they didn't burn. Oh, and I flattened mine a bit w/ a fork so they wouldn't have that mutant mountain look that oats do to cookies. They were pretty tasty, and had just the right sweetness.

text:
First, would like to say I am not an oatmeal cookie fan. More of a choc-chip kinda gal. Was baking these for a dear friend who cannot eat choc-chip due to migraines- oatmeal raisin is his fav. 
That said, I LOVED this recipe. I did two changes - #1 used all dark brown sugar - I was all out of white. #2 increased the cinnamon to 1 tsp. Used a mixer until I put in the raisins - but kept it running very low. Baked on aluminum cookie sheets with a piece of parchment on it - this resolved the sticky cookie difficulties. They turned out beautiful, tasted yummy.

text:
These are fabulous cookies!!  My husband just tried them and told me they are the best I've ever made (and I bake a lot!)  I made a few revisions based on previous reviews.  I doubled the recipe, mixed in a stand miser, reduced the sugars, added 1/2 c flour, added 1 tsp baking powder.  I also added craisins, dried cherries and dried blueberries, 1/2 c chopped almonds, and 1/2 c flax seeds (measurements for the double recipe). Letting them stand on the cookie sheet to cool for 3-4 minutes allowed them to be removed easily.  I agree that location (altitude) can make all recipes vary slightly so take that into consideration when making adjustments to recipes.  I was looking for the perfect "loaded oatmeal cookies".  I came across this recipe, added the extra ingredients I had in mind, and they turned out perfectly.  These are yummy!!!

text:
I read the reviews and made the following changes: boiled the raisins. Cut the butter in half and used half shortening (still get the butter flavor but makes a fluffier cookie) added 1 extra teaspoon vanilla, cut the white sugar down to 1/2 cup, bumped up the flour to 1 3/4 cups.  The oven temp was lowered to 350. I chilled them a bit while I was waiting for it to preheat. Rolled them in balls and baked 9min on a well seasoned cookie sheet. At 9min they came out perfect! Not flat, didn't stick, nicely browned bottom, chewy, the raisins were yummy! I think they are perfect now!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-12-11T14:57:54.643

text:
I have always followed the recipe off a box of oatmeal.  This time, we had the oatmeal without the box; therefore, Allrecipes.com here I come.  

I read through the reviews and made the following changes.  I used only brown sugar and did not use additional brown sugar because some had said the cookies were too sweet.  My family is not big on super sweets.  I also used fresh ground whole wheat flour.  My grinder is very fine, so the consistency of the batter was very good.

I modified the recipe accordingly:
1 C butter
1 C packed brown sugar
Removed white sugar
3 C oats

I felt the cookies came out very good.  My husband really liked them.  Since I am making them for church and for Father's Day, I made the cookies into heart shapes...

text:
Just made this.  A bit sweeter than I would like, but it still tastes great!  I took the advice about heating to 350.  I doubled the recipe since I was making a batch for the family and another for the school.  I also took the advice about soaking the raisins in warm water (I boiled a 1/2 cup in the microwave and then soaked the raisins).  The cookies came out like pralines with a bit more fluff in it.  I also used an IKEA kids' spoon to size the drops of cookie dough. I cooked for 10 minutes each on the middle shelf.  I put the cookies in a GladWare container with 1 piece of white bread to keep it soft.

text:
This was the first time I made cookies from scratch and this recipe was excellent. I think what I liked the most is that you can tweak it to your taste. I followed the advice of a few others and soaked the raisins and used 1 1/2c. of flour. Next time I will use more spices (nutmeg, more cinnamon, ground cloves). I cut back on the sugar as some suggested and used only brown sugar but next time I will add the sugar as the recipe calls for and I added walnuts. I don't understand how this could have possibly been runny as others have stated. When mixed, I got a good hearty dough and the cookies baked just like I like them with crispy edges and a nice chewy texture. Thanks so much for sharing this recipe it will definitely be a go to recipe for me!!

These turned out absolutely divine for me!  I followed past reviewer's advice and reduced the baking temp to 350 and increased the baking time to about 12 minutes, baked the cookies on top of a layer of aluminum foil, soaked the raisins first (I actually added craisens as well), and made sure to hand mix everything so as not to over work the dough.  They were moist, fluffy, and delicious!  Best oatmeal cookies I've ever tasted! (My husband even asked me to bake another batch so he could bring them to work to share with his coworkers!)

These cookies taste AMAZING. I love the soft and crispy edge texture. It's really the butter that does it, use real butter and make sure it is at room temp, otherwise expect uneven mixing. I like adding an extra egg just to make more moist cookies  Ive replaced raisins with craisins (dried cranberries), and it was awesome.  Ive also used this recipe to make a chocolate oatmeal cookie, just don't add raisins or cinnamon. My friends thought choc. oatmeal cookies was a nice twist.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
BEST oatmeal cookies ever!  I have no idea why people would give this recipe a bad review. I think they must have done something seriously wrong or have been baking on terrible cookie sheets.  I've made these twice so far and each time they came out perfect! Slightly crunchy outside and chewy inside--delicious! The first time I followed the recipe to a tee and of course, they came out good.  The second time I made them I only had margarine and not even quite enough.  I also lost track of how much oats I put in, so I think I screwed that up too.  And after THAT I ended up putting everything together in the wrong order. I was sure they weren't going to turn out, but they tasted great, if not better! Just in case you haven't baked a cookie of this consistency before, it's better to let the cookies slightly cool before removing it from the cookie sheet, otherwise, they may break while you try to remove them...but that's nothing new.  Also, I use a stoneware baking pan to bake cookies on, but I'm not sure if that necessarily makes them turn out any better.  So glad for this recipe and this is my new favorite cookie!

country:
None
text:
These cookies rawked.  The recipe works as is, but I also made bigger cookies with 3 additional minutes.  A shade crispy on the the edges, soft in the middle and slightly puffy...YUM!  I reduced the crispness on the bottom via a silicone baking mat, if desired.    Hints I use for reducing "runny" cookies (but I didn't use for this recipe): Use butter with at least 50% oil, or substitute a portion of white flour with a equal amount of sifted whole wheat (usually only a quarter of the total and max amount is 1/2 of total.), and don't forget to rotate the tray halfway through the baking time.    Future tweaks:  using nutmeg, apple spice and/or dried fruit/berries (rehydrate?)  *Note-also works well with replacing white sugar with Splenda.

I made this recipe today  with no alterations. I baked them for 8 minutes with no burning or falling. Cookies came out moist and tasty. I used unsalted room temperature butter. I find if I bake cookies using microwaved or melted butter/margarine, that they will fall flat and bake crisp/dry. I also have tried avoiding salted butter, as  I suspect the excess salt has been to blame for more than one batch of dried out cookies in the past. (but I am no Martha & I have no idea how to alter a recipe to correct it)

text:
I loved this recipe, atfer reading everyone's comments on this recipe I tested to see if I would have the same problem of the batter running but I didn't. Thats because I used this little trick, before you add the raisins coat them in 1 tablespoon of flour then add them and the oats to the batter. It stops the raisins from sticking together and it makes the cookie stay together and not run. My cookies came out perfect using that method. I hope this little hint was helpful.

text:
would be 5 stars AFTER all the recommended changes.  
my cookies turned out fine after I did the following:

 - cut brown sugar AND white sugar to 1/2 cup each.  
 - used 1/2 cup instead of 1 cup raisins
 - added 1/4 tsp cloves, 1/4 tsp nutmeg and 1/4 cup flour.  
 - baked to time required.  more like 20 min for first batch and 10-15 min per batch thereafter.  

i like the cookies after all the changes, but can't imagine liking them without all the additional ingredients.

 - one alternative instead of the cloves and nutmeg is to add another 1/2 to 1 tsp cinnamon

text:
I followed this recipe to the letter except that I did cut the sugars to one half cup each.  They turned out great.  I did mix my hand as there are few things I use my stand mixer for.  It's easy to over work things when you let a machine do the work.  You do have to let them cool for at least 8 minutes before you try to take them off the cookie sheet, otherwise they will fall apart.  That is the nature of the beast when using oatmeal in cookies.  Great recipe!!

crispy on the outside, chewie on the inside.  I used quick cooking oats.  Baked them for 9 min.  Make sure you let them sit for a minute then remove to cooking rack. country:
None
text:
Great oatmeal cookie--I followed the recipe except I soaked and blotted the raisins, and used 1 teaspoon of cinnamon and 1/2 teaspoon of nutmeg.  They turned out well.  Mine are thin, but still tasty.  When I looked at them after 8 minutes, I thought they looked way to wet to be done...I kept cooking until they appeared to be done.  Well...they are quite crisp after a couple of minutes out of the oven.  Subsequent trays were removed more promptly, and are not nearly as thin and crispy.  Next time I make them I will try some of the suggestions for making them a little "puffier"...but the extra cinnamon and nutmeg make the flavor perfect.  Thanks for a good recipe!

text:
I halved the recipe, used less than a quarter brown sugar (ran out of it), around a quarter white sugar and increased raisins to 3/4 cup, used instant oats (that's the only one I have at home). And it turned out just sweet enough. Follow the baking time if you prefer your cookies soft and chewy. I left mine in the oven for until brown as my husband likes his cookies harder. Overall, a really nice & easy recipe. Will be making it again. : )

text:
Mmm, I'm eating one right now!  This is a great recipe.  My only modifications were as follows (and out of necessity):   I only had a half cup of butter so I used margarine for the rest, and I ran out of brown sugar so the ratio was a little under cup of white to 1/2 a cup of brown.  I soaked the raisins in boiling water while I mixed up the dough.  Baked for about 11 minutes and they came out perfect - chewy and flavorful.  Thanks for the recipe Darlene!

None
text:
Considering that this recipe was so higly rated, I have to say I was a little disappointed. I found these to be a little tasteless and too sweet on the first batch, and so I added a teaspoon or so more cinnamon to the dough and they tasted much better. I also found that these were very difficult to store and eat whole, for they kept falling apart and sticking to one another (and I'm pretty sure they were properly cooked). I soaked the rasins, which gave a pleasent plumpness to them when the cookies were eaten, and I think that other than the points I've mentioned, these were quite enjoyable. Just enough oats and fruit and a nice flavour.

text:
This is a wonderful cookie- great texture, nice and chewy, and fabulous flavor. My kids love them! I always soak my raisins, so when I added them, the dough got a little sticky from the residual moisture. 1/4 c extra flour fixed that right up. Also added about 1/2 c extra raisins. Baked on cookie stone, as always. These are a flat cookie; if you're looking for a puffy, mounded cookie this isn't it.

text:
DO NOT CHANGE ANYTHING !  I was looking for a recipe that was a little crunchy but chewy and slightly soft.... THESE ARE PERFECT. For all the people that said too sweet, they are not. for all the people that said add more stuff....you don't have to. I didn't soak my raisins and they still tasted great in cookies.  I used 1 1/2 tbsp scoop to drop my cookies before baking and I didn't make mistake of letting butter get too warm before baking so they didn't spread out all over cookie sheet. I used quick oats, because they are cut thinner. Cookies were perfect,  just follow recipe exactly and wont have any issues.

text:
Not sure why so many people had trouble with this recipe. I made this recipe with the ingredients as written except I wanted two different kinds of cookies so before adding the raisins I divided the batter in two and added 1 cup of raisins to one batch and 1/2 cup dark chocolate chips, 1/2 cup dried cranberries to the other. Both varieties were absolutely delicious! I will definitely make these again. The only thing I adjusted was I baked at 350 instead of 375 so my cookies required about 14-15 minutes of baking time.  I used parchment paper and had no issues of spreading or flattening.

country:
None
text:
I started by adding an extra 1/4 cup of flour, doubled the  cinnamon.  I cut the sugars both to 1/2 cup.  Soaked 3/4 Cup raisins in hot water  (drain before adding shaking off extra water). I add 1/2 cup coconut, 1 Cup chocolate chips and 3/4 cup chopped nuts. I have found its important to use a cookie sheet with sides to get them to set right also cool in pans 2 minutes before placing on wire racks.  Test your oven as each is different  I bake mine  on 350 for eight minutes in mine but it's important to finish then on the sheets 2 minutes to set up.  Most the time I refrigerate the dough for 8 hours but an hour works.

text:
I made changes based on other reviews. I lowered the sugar (white & brown) to 1/2 cup each.  I added 1/4 tsp. Each cloves, Allspice & Nutmeg. I was liberal with the raisins & cinnamon. I mixed everything by hand & didn't overwork the dough. I soaked the raisins in hot water before draining & adding them at the end. I baked them at 325 degrees for 5-8 minutes & brought them out when they were golden around the edges. The family loved them!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Upon taking the suggestions of other reviewers, my cookies came out wonderfully. Soft, sweet, delicious!
These are the suggestions I followed:
-  I reduced the oven temp to 325 degrees (baked 10 min)
- I reduced the sugar to 1/2c of white and 1/2c of brown
- I used 1t of cinnamon, 1/4t of allspice, and 1/4t of nutmeg
- I whisked by hand instead of an electric beater
- I added more raisins and poured boiling water over the raisins to make them plump
- I sprayed my cookie sheet with nonstick oil
- I used a fork to flatten the cookies a little halfway through baking

text:
Made these night before last. I followed the recipe and yes, they fell flat and crisped too much all do to too much sugar. Before the second tray went in I added more flour and it helped balance out the sugars. The cookie itself is still too sweet but at least it's a cookie and not brittle. reduce sugar and increase flour and oats until the batter is slightly stiff and bake for an extra minute.

text:
Yummy! I had a craving for oatmeal cookies and whipped this up quick and easy. I added about double the cinnamon and 1/4 tsp clove and nutmeg; cut the white sugar down to 1/4 c. It's surprising to read about others' runny cookies. Mine were very fluffy; so much so that I'll squish them a bit before baking next time.

Runny batter is likely because the egg/butter/sugar mixture isn't beaten enough (should be fluffy like the recipe says) prior to adding dry ingredients and/or the batter gets overworked while adding dry ingredients.

I'm not a huge fan of oatmeal raisin cookies, but I made these for my husband and he loves them! He's already had four, and they haven't even finished cooling yet. This is what I did, and it worked great for me.

amanca

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum! I had no issues with this recipe. I took the suggestion of others and cut my white sugar to 1/2 cup and added a pinch of nutmeg. I did not have stand alone raisins so I used a package of mixed dried fruit (raisins, cranberries, cherries and blueberries). They were already moist so I did not need to plump them. I used my stand mixer for everything but the dried fruit and oatmeal which I incorporated by hand in three parts working till just blended. The mixture was quite sticky. I used two teaspoons to drop blobs onto parchment paper lined sheets. 8-9 minutes in oven at 350, just till edges are brown and then cool on sheet for a couple minutes before transferring to a cooling rack. I think the butter-based batters are often quite mushy when you first take them out, then they firm up. Agree with comments about watching them closely so they don't overcook. Will def make these again!

text:
PERFECT. I was looking for a good oatmeal cookie recipe and chose this one to try. Upon reading some reviews I mixed together a few tips and my batch came out PERFECT (if I say so myself). I only put in 1/2 cup with the sugars and to take care of the running problem added 1/4 cup flour and 1/2 teaspoon baking powder. Also, while mixing the batter I put a cup of raisins in a pot of hot water and put the stove on *very* low. By the time I needed to add them they were nice and plump.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1820801.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe with a few different suggestions left by others on this thread. First I added the extra 1/4 c of flour and 1/2 tsp of baking soda. I soaked the raisins in the slightly beaten eggs for about 15-20 mins while I measured  out the other ingredients. I omitted  the salt and used salted sweet cream butter instead, and only used 1/2 c of white sugar instead of the 3/4, added 1tsp of cinnamon and 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg. After you have your ingredients mixed let it chill in the freezer for 20 minutes. Have your oven preheated at 375, bake for 9minutes and make sure to rotate your baking sheet halfway through baking and let it stand at least  4-5min before transfering to wire rack. They tasted even better the next day. I ate 5 after they cooled and 4 more during breakfast. Definitely a good base recipe and with the tweaks made an even better one. ** as always make sure your eggs, butter and flour are at room temperature**

text:
Outstanding. But read the reviews first. I cut out the white sugar and
used 1 cup of coconut sugar, 1 tsp of cinnamon and reduced the baking
soda to 1/2 tsp. Then added 1/2 tsp each of baking powder and 1/2 tsp of Bakewell Cream. 

Instead of butter I added 3/4 cup soft coconut oil. Instead of wheat flour I added 2/3 c tapioca flour and 2/3 c of oat flour. Next time
a pinch of xanthan gum will help strengthen them.

I've made these cookies many times. I love this recipe exactly the way it is. I have not had the problems other reviewers have had. These are not runny cookies at all. The only thing for me is I like to bake organic, so I buy organic  bulk rolled oats & organic Thompson raisins in my local grocery store. I believe no matter what you are baking, quality ingredients are just as important as a great recipe. I use unbleached all purpose flour and have never had a problem, this cookie dough is always stiff and the cookies come out perfect every time. This will always be my go to for great oatmeal raisin cookies. Love them. Thanks

text:
in orden to bake anything successfully you must first understand melting point and the tricky nature of butter. i tried this recipe and i must say, it is good but not the best. since i grew up cooking with coconut  oil and coconut milk, butter has always been considered a flavor enhancer rather than a binding ingredient. also, whoever said egg whites was meant to be used in cookie recipes. blending the butter with a few tsp of coconut oil,coconut milk and nutmeg will eliminate problems associated with premature meltdown.

text:
I love this recipe! Although I did change it up a lil bit. I took the advice of the other ladies who reviewed and soaked the raisins in hot hot water in a small mesh colander for about 5 and that plumped them up. I also didn't feel like cutting up a stick of butter to get 3/4 cup, so I used both sticks and upped everything else by 1/4's except the eggs.  I stuck with only 2 eggs and they still came out delish.  Before I baked them tho,  I put the dough in the fridge for a few hours so it was easier to handle and the cookies didn't flatten out much. I also cooked them at 350 for 10 minutes but kept an eye on them. Best homemade oatmeal raisin cookies I've ever had!

Display Name:
crossleggedmoose

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a base recipe, this is fine, but I only gave this a 3 because I had make too many changes so it was not the original recipe in the end that I tested out.  I think the amount of sugar recommended is too sweet.  I cut back to 1/2 cup of white sugar and it was still too sweet personally.   I also used wholemeal flour and not white flour. I wanted to make mine a bit healthier so I added about 1/4 cup of ground flaxseeds.    My oven is super hot so baking at 190c started to brown them too quickly so I had to lower my oven down to 160c.  I also found that after just 9 minutes, they were turning really brown at the edges, but were just too soft even after cooling.  I ended up putting them back in the oven on low heat 150c for another 5 minutes and left them in the oven to cool. This created a much firmer cookie that held it's shape and still soft and chewy when bitten.    Some people said their cookies were flat when baked.  I had the opposite problem. My cookie dough mixture was very firm (even without cooling in the fridge) and I actually had to flatten the tops of them before baking otherwise they were just too thick in the middle.

This recipe was perfect.  The "only" thing I really did differently was soak my raisins in hot water at the beginning for about 10 minutes.

The cookies were chewy and not hard at all.  After three days they still taste fresh.  No more purchasing cookies from the local supermarket.

I would highly recommend making this recipe.  I was very hesitate after reading some reviews of the batter running while in the oven; however, using my amazing Kitchenaid mixer, made the recipe work like a charm.

Thanks for posting!

userID:
7887122
Display Name:
pdjingle
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am not a cook, baker, or super talented in the kitchen to say the least. I just started to really dive into cooking within the last 6 months. I have to say I have made these cookies about 4 times in the last 3 months alone. The best oatmeal cookies I have ever tasted ( and I have eaten a lot of OMR cookies in 26 years ) They came out soft in the middle and hard on top, and I could REALLY taste the cinnamon. They also freeze extreamly well, and great make ahead cookies!! 

Few things I did do differently after I made them a few times 

1. Plump the Raisins : I brought a cup of water to a rolling boil then added a splash of vanilla, a bit of cinnamon, brown and white sugar  and  and placed the half of cup of raisins in the water for about 10 to 15 min with the lid on. Took them off the heat and let them sit till the water was cool ( about a hour or so) Then drain them of ALL the excess water so you don't have soggy cookies. Use as normally would. It makes all the difference. 

2. After you make the cookie dough you must let it sit in the refrigerator for about 4 hours. This is not a deal-breaker but it just makes the flavor of the vanilla and cinnamon much more powerful. I found this out by accident when I was called about for the afternoon and put the dough in the fridge. I will never make cookies ..any cookies without letting it sit for an afternoon.

country:

text:
I've made these twice. Turned out perfect the first time, the second time, they didn't have as much flavor, so I sprinkled them with cinnamon. (obviously I did something wrong)
I'm getting ready to make them again. KEEP IN MIND.... this recipe calls for LIGHT brown sugar. Dark contains more molasses. I only ever have dark on hand, so I cut t with white sugar. I also used 1.5 cups of flour and added 1/2 tsp baking powder and 1/4 tsp cloves as others recommended.
I always use my silicone pan liners or parchment paper when baking. Never an issue with stuck cookies!
Bottom line.... A KEEPER!! Thank you for sharing, Darlene!

text:
After many modifications suggested in many other reviews, and a few of my own, they turned out well. For someone who has never made cookies from scratch this recipe and reviews of the recipe is a gook place to start. I reduced the recipe to half and I still reduced the flour to 2 cups instead of 2 1/2 as suggested. I halved the amount of brown and white sugar and added a little bit of honey. I used baking powder rather than soda I doubled the spices suggested, and added some apple butter I happened to have. I thought they weren't spicy enough, and kind of thick. My neighbors loved them though!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For those who love sweets but are watching calories and fat content, I used Splenda in place of white sugar, 1/2 cup brown sugar and substituted butter for 1/2 cup applesauce and 1/4 cup canola oil.

Taste was excellent however cookies didn't spread because of lack of butter and where a little cakey, but none the less good texture and flavor.

A NOTE for those who use butter... my baking experience with butter based cookies is after mixing everything, put the bowl in the fridge for 15 minutes to harden up the dough a bit and in between batches. helps a lot in keeping the cookies from spreading too much.

userID:
1565804
Display Name:
Angela G.
isPro:

0

0

5
favoritesCount:
80
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/84868.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome cookies!  Made a few changes as I wanted an applesauce/oatmeal cookie.  I used 1/2 c. butter and 1/2 c. applesauce; eliminated white sugar and used 1 c. of brown; 3/4 c. unbleached flour and 3/4 c. whole wheat; 1 t. of cinnamon and 1/2 t. nutmeg; soaked raisins in warm water while mixing the batter.  Baked for 10 minutes at 350 on parchment paper.  They turned out extremely soft and moist, didn't spread very much, which I like.  I didn't taste the applesauce very much, but I wouldn't increase it without adding more flour.  Not sure what that would do to the texture.  All in all, a very yummy cookie!  I might substitute chocolate chips next time for the raisins.

text:
If you like your cookies moist and chewy, refrigerate the dough for 10-15 min. before baking them. Drop the dough onto the cookie sheets and refrigerate, then bake until the top is golden. I did this unintentionally and they came out GREAT! I love chewy cookies even though my sons prefer them crunchy.

text:
I did tweak this with a little more flour and less sugar (1/2 C white, 3/4 C  brown). I also used white whole wheat flour, which adds some fiber. I rolled the dough into balls, which made for very nice, puffy cookies. As others have noted, don't use a mixer after creaming the butter and sugar. Mix it in by hand and DON'T overmix.

I have only made an account so I could review this recipe. text:
These were a hit! Read a lot of reviews on this and changed 2 things. I used 1 cup of brown sugar and 1/2 cup of white sugar. I also added 1 full teaspoon of cinnamon. I soaked the raisins in warm water for an hour before adding them to the mixture, they were perfect. I used quick cooking oats instead of rolled oats. I've made this recipe 3 times now. My friends and family loved them. I've already shared this recipe with 2 other people, will keep spreading this one around.

country:

text:
Just Perfect!  I often find when following a recipe exactly as it is written the first times leaves little room for disappointment.  I did this, only adding a little nutmeg and ground cloves to the cinnamon(I'm a spice girl).  8 and 1/2 minutes is the magic baking time for me and my oven.  They came out wonderful.  To those who had a bad experience I cant imagine why if the directions were followed.  All I can guess is a runny consistancy can result from MELTING the butter instead of SOFTENING it.  Also I have never heard of presoaking the raisins, it is completely unneccesary and would also add to a runny texture, as a result of too much moisture.  Anyway, I misplaced my standby recipe.  I'm glad I did, I found this one and it's my new go to oatmeal cookie recipe!

text:
I have made this recipe twice, once with rolled oats and the second time with quick oats (didn't add raisins either time since I don't care for them).  I preferred it with quick oats.  Using the quick oats, I baked them for 7 minutes at 360 degrees (8 minutes for the rolled oats).  The second time I also added about 3 tablespoons extra flour.  I also added peanut butter chips (both times) which went really well with the oatmeal.  They were quite the hit at work!  I should have made a double batch because they didn't even last half the day.  Will definitely make again with the peanut butter chips!

Not sure what happened, the cookies came out tasting fine, but the consistancy was all wrong.  Too crumbly; most of them broke when I removed them from the cookie sheets.  I reduced the sugar by about a third, and they were still more than sweet enough.  I increased the cinnamon and added a pinch of cloves. This turned out great!  I halved the recipe and added 1/4 c extra flour and about 1/4 tsp b. powder, but judging by how well they kept their shape, I'm not sure I needed it.  I also added chocolate chips instead of raisins and cooked them on 350.  One tip for people who were having problems: if you grease the baking sheet, the cookies will spread while cooking!! make sure it is ungreased!  Thanks for posting, I will definitely keep this recipe around!

text:
After reading the reviews about the cookies spreading too much, I was determined to make it work.  I chilled my dough for about an hour and a half before baking the cookies and I had no problems.  They required about 13 minutes to bake, but they turned out beautifully.  I always soak my raisins for baking in boiling water to soften them, and this time I got the inspiration to add some rum.  I really liked the additional zip that gave the cookies and would do it again.  Overall I was very pleased with these cookies.  They have a nice outer crunch with a softer center, and taste just like an oatmeal raisin cookie should.

text:
This recipe is, unfortunately, unusable without changes which is why I can't give it more than two stars. When you initially put the ingredients together (following the recipe line by line), it ends up looking like batter rather than dough.   I had to add an additional 1/2 cup + of flour to it. Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2010-06-12T17:19:45.923
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4961262
Display Name:
MrsWAW
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
45
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1166003.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had to make adjustments based on what was in the house.  Thankfully, all of them resulted in a better cookie than I would have gotten if I had stuck to the given recipe!   I only had one stick of butter, which turned out to be a good thing from the reviews of greasiness.  I've learned to always use at least 1 tsp of cinnamon.  I wondered if they were really serious with that 3/4 tsp.?  I also added nutmeg.  The only white sugar I had was powdered, so I used it and am glad I did.  My butter wasn't soft and I think that was a good thing.  I melted it down some on the warmer and then just cut up the rest of the cold butter into cubes.  I also simmered the raisins in warm water and cinnamon so they would be plumper, which is good.  I let the batter rest so it wasn't too runny before I put it on the cookie sheet.  I usually make cookies bigger than the recipes and that avoids them being too crispy - a good call for this particular recipe!  I fit about six on a cookie sheet.  The baking time was off so I just baked until they didn't look raw in the middle.    With these changes to the given recipe, the taste was great and so was the texture.  They weren't too crispy and didn't stick to the cookie sheet.  I ended up with yummy, chewy cookies that my family loved.  Unfortunately, this recipe needs too many changes in order to have yummy chewy cookies.  Next time I will just use the box top recipe.  I'm not printing this one out or saving it.

text:
Amazing Cookies!! However instead of putting the oatmeal as it is I blend it in a food processor beforehand that way the oatmeal is more combined and not as Chunky.Beforehand my family didn't like oatmeal cookies because you could taste the chunks and pieces of oats, now the cookies are devoured and everyone says they are DELICIOUS!!! I did however also cut the sugar a bit and only put 1/2 cup of each type of sugar and it was perfectly sweetened! I will def be making these cookies again. Also I add about 1/4 cup extra flour , without it I find that the cookies don't keep their shape, and are a bit too flat

text:
ADD MORE FLOUR& BAKING SODA!! I broke my cardinal sin when baking from allrecipes, I forgot to read the reviews. These cookies taste perfect, but they fall flat, you need to add more flour and baking soda (1/4 c flour and 1/4 tsp of baking soda) they will fall flat and be runny if you don't. But, like I said taste wise these cookies are perfection! BTW, the batch I just cooked without the extra flour and baking soda, will somehow still manage to get eaten ;)

text:
These were DELICIOUS, especially warm! I did make some modifications based on other users experiences. I increased the flour by 1/4 cup to reduce the flattening. I was short of oatmeal, so I reduced it to only 1 1/4 cups. Instead of raisins I chose to use chocolate chips. I baked them on a non-stick, ungreased cookie sheet for 7-8 minutes. They were the perfect thickness, size and taste! My husband's not a big cookie eater, but he devoured them! Thanks for the tasty recipe! This is definitely a keeper!

text:
YUM! ADVICE: Definitely go with the extra 1/4C flower and 1/4t baking soda. Bring raisins to a boil and then take them off heat let them soak while making the mix. ALSO Im a huge spice fan so I added 1/4t nutmeg and then 1/8t ground black pepper.. sounds weird but it just gives it a delicious flavor boost! Also I used LESS SUGAR. I find that decreasing the sugar in most cookie recipies by a good 1/4C make SO little difference.. and especially with the raisins being so sweet already. Definitely making this again.

text:
I made these cookies twice.  The firstime I baked them on an insulated cookie sheet and they were flat and greasy.  The next time I baked them on a shiney non-insulated cookie sheet and they turned out perfect.  Do not use an insulated cookie sheet when baking cookies with butter or oleo.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have had these cookies requested by dozens of people after I made them the first time.  The trick is not to bake them for the longest time, 8 minutes at MOST for me, they will not look done, but they are!  Also, make sure that they are allowed to cool on the baking sheet for approx 5 minutes prior to moving them to a cooling rack, otherwise they can be a soft gooey mess.  I also found that you absolutely can NOT melt the butter, it MUST be soft, but not melted if you want your cookies to turn out top notch.  EXCELLENT recipe, I make them at least once a month for family and friends.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had trouble with my first batch of "test cookies": they turned out really flat.  After talking to my mom, she suggested that I chill the dough between batches, chill the pan, and lower the rack in my oven to one below center.  That helps the bottom of the cookies set sooner so they can't spread so much.  After making those changes, I had pretty good results.  I used chocolate-covered dried cherries instead of raisins, and substituted about 1/3 of the flour for whole wheat flour.  I also added a few extra spoons of flour because one reviewer mentioned the recipe needing more.  I'm pretty picky, so the fact that I'm willing to give these cookies as a gift shows that I liked them quite a bit.

I just baked these cookies for the first time and they turned out GREAT!!  The only things I did differently were, instead of beating in the dry ingredients I folded them in my by hand. text:
I wated to be nice and bake my grandfather some Oatmeal Rasin Cookies for his 76th birthday, as they are his favorite! I could not find my recipe that I usually use because we moved recently, and this one looked compatible. Seriously, the batter tasted great, but once they were cooked the cookies  flattened out and hardened immediately! I had to scrape them off my non-stick cookie sheets! For the second set that went into the oven, I reduced the amount of dough for each cookie AND the cook time! Same thing! And the third sheet I reduced the cook time even more - I was down to like 7 to 8 minutes at the provided temperature! All were hard as rocks!

text:
After reading the reviews- I changed the recipe slightly and the cookies were WONDERFUL!
Hand mix for sure all the ingredients and then I was able to roll into balls, and flatten slightly.
I increased the flour to 1 3/4 c, increased the oats to 3 C, and increased the baking soda to 2 tsp.
I also used 1 cup of chocolate covered raisins, and 1/2 cup of regular raisins.
EVERYONE LOVED these cookies! They raised well and had an excellent flavor! Will make them again and again!

text:
This recipe was fantastic! I did have to toss the first batch, but my oven was running extremely hot. I reduced the heat to 350 degrees an the rest of the cookies came out beautifully. The trick for me was letting these cookies sit on the pan for a couple of minutes before I moved them to the rack, or they would fall apart because they were just too warm. Sent these to husband's office, didn't get a single one back!

text:
This is a delicious oatmeal raisin recipe! The cookies come out soft and chewey...They are delicious! I didn't have light brown sugar on hand so I substituted with dark brown, but I changed the measurement to 1/2 cup (I still used 3/4 cup of the white sugar). I also used a teaspoon of cinnamon instead of 3/4 tsp. Overall, I'm very glad I found this recipe! For me, these cookies didn't spread out flat at all. They came out perfect. I'll definately make them again and again.

text:
The cookies became really runny on the cookie sheet,several of them turned into giant globs of oatmeal cookie, lol.  They *are* thin, as many have said, but I sort of enjoyed the crisp edges and softer middles.  I like fluffy cookies also, but the "thinness" didn't bother me.  I always grease the pan though, so I didn't have any problems getting them off.

I might make the recipe again...

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As for taste, this cookie is fantastic. But I do have to agree with other reviewers--the cookie flattens out a whole lot and breaks easily (I had some trouble getting them off the cookie sheet. I would recommend greasing, though the recipe doesn't call for it.) I don't remember anyone else commenting on it, but this recipe makes more than 48 for sure! I made them bigger than the recipe said to, yet I made 5 dozen--with a little extra batter left to spare. And that's with my cookies getting progressively bigger by each batch. For the bigger cookies, I just turned down the temp 20 degrees and cooked an extra one or two minutes. I also didn't put cinnamon since I discovered that I didn't have any after already starting--oops. But it still turned out tasty.

text:
This cookie recipe is great!  My husband and son, both chocolate cookie lovers and oatmeal haters, LOVED this cookie.  I did alter the recipe a bit--I used 1 c brown & 1/2 cup white sugars, doubled the cinnamon and added 1/2t nutmeg. This cookie does spread while baking, so it is really important to heap the dough on the baking sheets.

city:
