region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. I followed the recipe and the cookies came out great. I read other reviews and some said their cookies came out dry. So this is what I did:

Soaked the  raisins in vanilla extract and 1/2 cup of Baileys Irish Cream

Added more of:

3 TBSP of butter
1 more TBSP of cinnamon 
A pinch more of salt

My batter was a little wet so when you scoop it onto the parchment just form them into round circles, I pat mine down so they would bake evenly (donโt like soggy cookies!) I baked them on parchment paper (on the cookie sheet)  and when they were golden brown, I let them cool for 5 minutes, then I inverted them onto the baking sheet, baking  the underside to make them crispy on both sides. They were delicious with  that CRUNCH! 
 Hands down a simple and easy recipe. I had some left over batter so I sealed the rest in a Tupperware to bake throughout the week. 
Thank you for this easy and delightful recipe! My kitchen smells wonderful!

First time making this! Loved this bread! Only 2 changes. I used 2 cups of sugar and 1/2 c oil and 1/2 cup  applesauce for the 1 cup of oil. Followed recipe except per others' suggestions: soaked raisins, cut white sugar to 1/2c, added 1/4t allspice, 1/4t ground cloves.
To try and preserve the body of the cookie, I was careful to barely mix the dry into the wet, then minimally fold in the raisins.
Result: held together perfectly, sweet enough, tasted good although no cloves next time.

text:
This recipe is great. As Iโve grown more comfortable with it Iโve modified it a bit and my most recent modifications won a little baking contest. Iโve posted below if youโre interested...

- Double the called-for cinnamon, so 1.5 tsp
- Add 50% more vanilla, so 1.5 tsp
- Use โGoldenโ raisins instead of traditional, 1 full cup
- Add craisins, 1/4 cup
- Chill overnight

I donโt know why, but chilling the dough and scooping it out with an ice cream scoop while still chilled REALLY impacts this. The cookies turnout AMAZING.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe made delicious cookies with a couple of tweaks. Iโm giving it 4 stars since I donโt think it would be as good without my changes to the recipe. I donโt like oatmeal raisin cookies but these turned out amazing! I took the recommendation of another reviewer and mixed the dry ingredients into the wet by hand, which gave me a nice fluffy cookie. I used my mixer when creaming the butter and mixing the rest of the wet ingredients though. 

Other changes:
1) increased cinnamon to 1 tsp
2) freshly ground the spices (added 1/2 tsp or less of nutmeg, clove, and a little allspice) in my mortar and pestle, then poured it through a sieve to make sure only finely ground pieces made it in
3) soaked the raisins in hot water for an hour
4) chilled the dough for an hour
5) decreased sugar to 1/2 c of brown sugar and 1/2 c white sugar.

Making sure the butter is cold when the cookies go into the oven is the best way to avoid flat, crispy cookies. Thatโs why I chilled the dough, along with the fact thatโs the flavors mesh well together.

text:
I gave this three stars as I made the dough exactly as the recipe stated (except I accidentally added almost double the cinnamon but that turned out in my favour) and followed baking directions (didnโt leave them alone but put them in for the minimum time specified) and they ended up burnt. Then I started playing around with the dough and oven temperature. I added an extra 1/4cup of flour as I found they were spreading too much, reduced the temperature to 345 and tried again... still too flat and burnt. So I stuck the dough in the fridge overnight, scooped some out and baked at 300 for 8 mins and they came out perfect. I let them cool on the sheet to set up a bit but they are delicious. I really recommend nd reading the reviews and using a timer to help you keep track. If you take them out when the edges are just cooked (tiny bit golden) they will be perfect

I will definitely be making this recipe again!! However, I did make a few adjustments. I added 1 tsp of apple cider vinegar to help the baking soda fluff up the cookies a bit. I also used flax โeggsโ instead of chicken eggs and vegan โbutterโ instead of regular butter (Iโm vegan). I ended up baking the cookies for 11 minutes instead of 8-10. With the adjustments I made, these cookies turned out perfectly chewy and delicious! They remind me a lot of the oatmeal raisin cookies sold at Subway sandwich shops (which used to be my favorite)!

text:
Original recipe had too much butter and not enough flour. The cook time for me was 15 min. I reduced butter by 6 tablespoons. After the first batch at 10 min was still raw in the middle and merged into a flat pancake on the cookie sheet, I added more flour until the consistency was like normal cookie dough.  After that, the cookies were amazing. A huge hit!!

text:
These are wonderful! Best oatmeal cookies I've ever made! Not ever going back to my old recipe.  
I added 1/4 cup more flour, as was suggested by others in the comments. Also, if you only use teaspoonfuls of dough, your cookies will be really small. I used heaping tablespoons of dough and had a nice sized cookie.
For a variation, omit cinnamon and raisins. Add 1 cup chocolate chips and 1 tablespoon peanut butter. Yummy!

text:
I made this true to the recipe but had to make slight (very slight) tweaks just before baking, for obvious reasons, or there's no way I'd have kept these. The batter is too wet and thin with the recipe as is, that you're going to have to put more flour, oats, & soda. It'll also be painfully sweet, especially with the thinness of the dough, so cut the sugars โ I used less brown and a little less granulated, but it's still quite obviously sweet. It is okay considering my slight fixes, but it'd definitely be at a 1 star-rating otherwise.

Great base to make any changes you like.  I used cherries instead of raisins and added chocolate chips.  I soaked the dried cherries in boiling water then drained before adding. Perfect!

text:
We did not care for these cookies at all. I consider myself a fairly seasoned baker. My friends and family get so excited when they find out I'm baking something. I followed this recipe to a "T" and the cookies came out as flat, chewy discs. It's like the batter disentigrated and the oats are being held together with a rubbery glue. According to notes I found after the fact made by other bakers, adding more flower and baking powder help keep this from happening. This has been a complete waste of time. You're better off using the recipe from the Quaker Oats container.

text:
Went for diabetic. Used sugar substitutes, and 1/4 cup applesauce for 1/4 cup butter. Added 1 1/2 teaspoons of cinnamon, 1/2 teaspoon cardomon, 1/2 teaspoon allspice, & increased raisins to 1 1/2 cups, after plumping them. Also added 1/4 cup flax & 1 tablespoon of chia seeds. Refrigerated dough for 1 hour. After 8  minuets of baking turned cookies over & cooked for 2 more minutes. Excellent chewy cookies not too sweet. Healthy for a breakfast on the run.

text:
This recipe looks good, but for me as with so many others it came out flat, runny, burnt. After adding a total of 1 cup flour, 1/2 tsp baking soda, and reducing oven to 350 I got 3 edible batches out of 5. Others said they added flour, reduced oven temp, refrigerated dough, made balls instead of spoonfuls, and hand mixed. At what point does it become a different recipe?  It's misleading to make sometimes a significant change such as 25 degrees less oven temp then give a recipe (any recipe) a high rating. I would love it if somehow there could be a category of "no changes made" with a rating for that.  I have to also mention that I made these cookies only once, it shows twice because of a glitch on my tablet.

I looked at some reviews and made a few changes, which I do not always do. Added 1/4 tsp allspice, 1/4 tsp cloves, 1/4 c flour, 1/2 tsp baking powder.  I did cut back a little on both sugars -probably put in 2/3 c of each and regretted doing that. I also soaked my raisins in hot water and let them dry off a little before stirring in. Used 1/2 old fashioned oats and 1/2 quick oats because it was all I had.  Baked 9 min per tray. Turned out great except that next time I'd add the full amt of sugar.

I made these after reading through the reviews, and did make a few changes.  I added 1/2 cup flour, before refrigerating for 30 minutes. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5799229.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I decided to make these following and after reading many reviews, I lowered the heat to 325 degrees and put them in 6 minutes originally and then stood by the stove for another 2 minutes and another 1 minute. After this,  the edges and bottom were brown. I took them out and let them sit. Because I used my kitchen aid blender, others were right about the mixture being soupy. I let them sit for 15 mins and  came out thin but tasted great. I had half of the batch left in the bowl so I added a 1/4 cup of flour and a 1/2 teaspoon of baking Soda. I used a melon baller this time to put them on a cookie sheet for 6 minutes and another 3 minutes at 1 minute intervals. These ones were smaller and the texture was perfect! I recommend as someone else said adding a 1/4 cup of extra flour if you want a more solid cookie texture but still taste great but if you mix them and they come out thin. ITs a personal preference imo. I made them for my boyfriend for a hunting trip for him and his friends. He loved them!

I followed the recipe exactly and the cookies were delicious!

text:
Just the way I like them! Not too spicy and perfectly moist. The only reason I didn't give them 5 stars was because I made slight changes suggested by another reviewer. 
I added 1/4 cup extra flour and 1/2 tsp extra baking soda to keep them from running. I also soaked the raisins in hot tap water while mixing the batter. The suggestion to pour them into a colander and place them on a saucepan worked perfectly. Because my oven tends to burn cookies on the bottom, I raised the oven rack up one slot and baked them for 10 min. Very yummy!

text:
I made these using only 1/2 cup of white and 1/2 cup of brown sugar and kept everything the same. Baked at 170 degrees C for about 8-10 minutes or until golden brown. They came out sweet enough for my liking (I do have a high tolerance for sugar and think the original amount of sugar would have been too sweet). I did not have any issues with the cookies being runny, instead they kept their shape and only rise and spread a little. The cookies came out crunchy instead of chewy but they are still a keeper. I live in NZ so I think the ingredients here may slightly be different to what I would get in the States.

text:
This recipe is very good. I inadvertently misread the amount of flour and added an extra 1/2 cup. This did not by any means meant trouble. I however did consider the suggestions of adding 1/2 cup of each of the sugars and probably add a bit of another spice. For me it was a bit of nutmeg. My cookies came about as I expected them: round, chewy, sweet enough, and flavorful. By the time they cool completely they came out a bit crispy on the outside but soft on the inside. Will make it again and will definitely be my go to/base recipe for oatmeal raisin cookies. BTW, I did not soak the raisins in water and it was good.

text:
We regularly use this recipe to make home made ice cream sandwiches. I scoop and bake the cookies, and then I freeze them. I melt ice cream slightly, then I lay it in a cookie sheet to refreeze. Once both the cookies and the ice cream is ready, I cut the ice cream and assemble. I then bag up each sandwich individually, and refreeze. Delicious!

text:
I read the other review and only used 1/2 c white sugar and 1/2 c brown sugar and used 1 t cinnamon. It was great. I also used parchment paper so I had no problem with sticking.  In measuring the flour I was generous with my measurement because of some of the other peoples complaints, and because I had cut back on my other dry ingredient, the sugar.  There was no reason to do this as they turned out perfect, it was obvious that they would never came close to melting as some complained about.  I will use this recipe again.  They were great. If you love super sweet cookies follow the recipe as is and you will do fine.  I do like the extra cinnamon though.

text:
First batch was exactly as written. They were pretty good in my opinion, a classic oatmeal raisin cookie. The second batch I added more cinnamon, cloves, and allspice and mixed in some craisins. Mmmm, sooooo much better! A little sweet though so next time I'll cut some sugar out. 

I did notice they stick to the pans, even with a ton of cooking spray. I let them cool before removing though, and used a thin spatula. Worked great! I also used room temp butter, I'm not sure if that helped mine stay cookie shaped or not. 

Overall, I'll probably make again.

userID:
20726905
Display Name:
Christopher
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4130653.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies where great and did not last at all. The best advice I can give anyone having a hard time with this would be to not use an electric mixer on the badder. You over mix this kind of cookie and it goes flat. The butter and stuff? Mix it with an electric mixer (You can make the butter sugar eggs fluffy with a mixing spoon or anything really, but that will take a long time. I did it that way just to see if I could and it worked even though it's a bit of a workout), just when you add the flour into the butter use a mixing spoon and fold in the raisins or just don't mix them too much. 

One last thing that needs mentioning, don't use the microwave to soften the butter because that also makes flat cookies. If the butter is too cold and you want to jump right into making these cookies (Any cookie) cut the butter up into small pieces and mix them that way until the small chunks of butter are soft enough to blend together and then add the rest of the ingredient as the recipe says, however, that part needs to be done by hand because cold butter is not soft and will stick to an electric mixer.

Butter that is too cold is one of the main causes of ruined cookies, next to over mixing the badder. 

If they don't turn out the way you would have imagined they should try again. Making messed up cookies does not mean you're bad at making cookies, it just means you need to keep practicing. Trial and error, that's how we all learn.

I have never made cookies before, so this was an experiment.  I chose this recipe because it looked simple enough.  I did read all the reviews but the only change I made in the recipe was to cut it in half because I didn't know how it would turn out.  With the first batch, at about 4 minutes of baking I was concerned because they weren't spreading, so I took the pan out of the oven and gently pushed down on each cookie with a fork. I like this recipe and I'm going to experiment with other cookie recipes now.

text:
I was actually surprised on how well it worked after such mixed reviews. I followed the recipe pretty closely (with the exception of adding another 1/4 tsp of cinnamon and a dash of nutmeg). They came out soft and chewy. Some tips to get them to come out this way without adjusting the recipe is to soak the raisins in warm water while you're preparing the batter (drain them before use), and to stir the batter by hand to get the right consistency. If you're getting all 48 cookies like I did, they need to be pretty small, but they bake up to a decent size. Mine baked at 350 for about 7-9 minutes, depending on the batch.

This is the perfect oatmeal raisin cookie recipe. I've made them much more than the 4 times I marked on here. The only time they "spread out" on the baking sheet was the very first I made them. I had used non-stick cooking spray and those first 9 cookies thinned and stuck to the pan. Those 9 cookies, however, tasted great. They just weren't as pretty. 

When I made them the second time I added dried cranberries and pecans along with the raisins.  My boyfriend loved them, I loved them and my coworkers loved them. 

This recipe has been added to my tried and true favorites list. That may not seem significant, but that list includes my mother's blondies (secret family recipe,) her sugar cookies, her peanut butter cookies, and my almost famous banana nut bread. 

Most definitely a must-have

Excellent recipe.  Almost like the one on the oatmeal box.  I did use 1 packed cup of brown sugar and 1/2 cup of reg sugar.  I used 3 cups of oatmeal and added an extra egg, so 3 eggs.  Used 1 tbsp less of butter.  I added 1/4 cup more of flour cause of our high altitude here in Denver.
They were so sticky, even with a spoon to put on "parchment paper"., so I rolled them into balls making sure my hands were coated with flour.  
They came out perfecto!!  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
This recipe came out great, although I used it mostly as a guideline. At the time, I didn't have regular flour so I instead opted for 100% whole wheat and substituted the brown sugar for Poloncillo: which is a latin very dark brown sugar which comes in a cone. I also couldn't find raisins so I used white chocolate chips and they're a hit. In my oven I opted for 11 minutes and broiled the cookies for an additional minute and a half to add a crisp outside. I hope this helps.

text:
I loved these cookies! I used only 1/2c of brown sugar and 1/2c of white sugar. I added more cinnamon, nutmeg and allspice. I put mine in the fridge prior to baking to keep the dough firm. I didnt use the mixer, i think that would over mix it and would lead to runny cookies. With most cookies or brownies i always mix by hand and gently fold in the ingredients. Will definately make this again!

Loved these cookies the only thing i did differently was used a half cup less quick oats  and a half cup more raisins in a double batch.. this recipe will definitely be my go to from now on.

 If your having issues with your cookies spreading thin while cooking try chilling your baking sheets and cookie dough in the fridge. While one tray is in the oven cooking,  have the other chilling...this will stop your cookies from spreading flat

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1903436.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for the first time today.  After I had the first batch in the oven I came to read these reviews.  I saw that some people said they spread out too much and some said they came out hard.  I also noticed that it says to drop by a teaspoon on an ungreased cookie sheet.  A teaspoon is pretty small so I would imagine it was meant to say heaping or rounded spoonful.  I had cut down the recipe so I was dealing with amended measurements.   I followed the amended measurements exactly, except for adding 1/2 cup of Hershey's semi-sweet chocolate chips to the recipe and although the amended ingredients called for  1 & 1/2 eggs,  I used 2 eggs.  I used an even measure of a size small cookie scoop, lined the cookie sheets with parchment paper and baked at the 375 F temperature as directed for 11 minutes.  The cookies came out lightly browned on the bottom and edges and soft and chewy otherwise.  They are delicious and my husband said they are a favorite of his!  Whatever size spoon you use though, you always have to watch the cookies and judge the baking time by their sight as to when they're done.  Lightly browned on the edges and on the bottoms are done!
Review:
Rating:
3

text:
These cookies are amazing! I am a terrible baker. After four failed attempts at making cookies for my boyfriend, I found this recipe and tried it out. It was so easy to make and they came perfectly. 

As mentioned above, I am no baker, but I think it's really important for the butter to be SOFT and not MELTED. If the dough is on the liquid-y side, the cookies will melt into discs. 

I also follow cooling directions closely. I let these sit on the cookie sheet for about 30 seconds after taking them out of the oven, then move them to a cooling rack. 

Wonderful cookies. A new favorite!

None
text:
I have to disagree with a couple points in the most helpful review. I tried their suggestion to reduce sugar and reduced the white sugar to 1/2 cup. The cookies were not sweet enough. I tried their suggestion to cook at 325 and after 14 minutes my cookies still were not browning on the edges. I turned my oven up to 350 and the remaining batches still took at least 12 minutes. I will leave my oven at 375 next time.
I soaked the raisins in hot water and added 1/4 cup extra flour. I added 1/2 tsp Baking Powder. I used 1 tsp Cinnamon, 1/4 tsp Nutmeg, and 1/2 tsp Allspice. The Allspice adds an interesting new flavor, you will have to decide if you like it or not yourself.

text:
I used to always get frustrated with flat cookies when following the recipe on the Quaker oats lid.  I finally tried again following the advice of other reviewers and added 1/4 cup more flour along with 1 tsp of baking powder in addition to the baking soda the recipe calls for and I added a pinch more cinnamon and a pinch of nutmeg along with chopped walnuts and my cookies finally came out perfect! They were delicious and my family couldn't get enough! I'm so relieved after all these years I can finally make my own oatmeal raisin cookies! 5 stars!

text:
This was the best Oatmeal Raisin recipe I've tried yet! My husband is a huge oatmeal raisin fan, and this recipe was finally the one to win his heart! I used 3/4 cup Tenderflake in place of butter, 1/2 cup sugar, 1/2 cup brown sugar, and beat in the dry ingredients gradually, by hand. I used 1 tsp. cinnamon (instead of 3/4), 1/4 tsp. nutmeg, 1/4 tsp. cloves, and 1/4 tsp. allspice to spice the batter. I then used a 1 Tbsp. cookie scoop to distribute the batter on ungreased pans. I baked for 10 minutes each and they were perfect, chewy, and delicious! My husband couldn't stop eating them!

text:
These are ok.  Make sure you use parchment paper as the cookies will stick on some sheets. I used two different ones, and my Williams Sonoma sheet stuck, the USA pan did not. I also had to cook them for 12 minutes in my Thermador oven, not 8-10. I would also add some cloves for next time, as these are pretty bland. They are flat, but that didn't bother anyone. All in all, I think this recipe could be tweaked to make it better. I'm always mystified when people say it's a great recipe but they've made big changes to it!

text:
Very good!  Mixed on high speed using a hand held mixer to whip the sugars, eggs, butter and vanilla (using 1/2 c each of the sugars as suggested).  Hand mixed in flour and spices.  Was generous with the spices using 3t cinnamon and 1/2t each nutmeg and allspice (because that is what i had).  Had dried cranberries and raisins from left over salad mixes so I added these at the end (after soaking in boiling water).  Will make again :-)

text:
My first test batch came out flat and a really darkr.  However, once they dried, I crumbled them up and filled a Dixie cup with the mix and handed it to my husband and told him it was home made granola.  He liked it!  lol! But really, after that batch I added a little more than 1/4 th cup of extra flour and lowered the oven to 355 degrees.  I watched them carefully and they came out great at 10 minutes baking time. Oh well...live and learn.  That's why I always make a "test batch" of 6 cookies.

text:
I changed the recipe.  I added an egg yolk to increase the chewy factor. Instead of raisins, I used dried apricots cut into raisin size pieces.  Instead of cinnamon, I used powdered ginger.  To add to the ginger flavor and to give these cookies just a little bit of heat, I added in finely chopped crystalized ginger and a tablespoon of grated fresh ginger.  A little upgrade from the standard cookie and very yummy. Thank you to my husband and brother for cutting up the ginger and apricots.

None
country:
None
text:
Baked up beautifully... with modifications 

I read through the reviews and followed the recipe with the following modifications: reduced sugar to 1/2 cup each white and brown; added 1/4 cup flour, 1/2 tsp baking soda, 1/4 tsp each of ground cloves and allspice. Baked @ 350 for 11 mins. They are perfect looking cookies and just the right amount of chewiness for an oatmeal raisin cookie. They still could've used more spice in my opinion, but I like a spicy oatmeal cookie.

text:
I feel like this is a baseboard recipe. Something to build off of and maybe not so "tried and true". I took Ms. Becky Black's advice and added the 1/4 cup more of flour and the extra 1/2 tap of baking powder to prevent running  a flatness. I would suggest using 2 1/4 cups of oats instead. The amount listed was actually overwhelming. Lastly, placing the raisins in hot or boiling water would definitely give them that plump look and fluffy taste. 

** I also added shaved coconut in mine. :)

text:
Made this recipe almost as stated (used dried cranberries instead of raisins).  I did have a problem with running and I used a cookie scoop for measurement.  The more I packed them in before dropping the less they ran so that may be the key to the perfect bake.  My bake time was also more like 11 minutes and I have a gas oven which tends to bake faster.  They turn quick so you def have to watch during baking.
They are good but I do think they could use a little more flavor thus the 4 star rating.

None
country:
None
text:
I have made these twice now and they have turned out great both times. In response to the negative reviews about the cookies spreading or the cookie dough being too wet- it is probably due to the raisins being soaked in water. The recipe is NOT to blame, because the recipe does not instruct you to soak the raisins. I did, however, soak the raisins, but I patted them dry with a paper towel before adding them in the second time which really made a difference. I also took the advise of another reviewer and baked them at 350 for 9 minutes and that worked really well for me also.

text:
Sometimes I wonder about ppl's reading comprehension skills vs baking.  I didn't change anything on basic ingredients and cookies are perfect.  Now since this was my 3rd time using this recipe I jazzed it up...added 1/4 tsp cardamom, added 1/4 tsp allspice, upped the cinnamon to 1 tsp.  Added 1/4 tsp almond extract.  For the plumping of raisins, I had made myself a pot of Earl Grey and used the leftover tea as the soaking liquid.  I'm really delighted with the outcome.  Already had a neighbor ask what I did differently.

text:
Update: Oh drat! I forgot to read my own notes. I just made this recipe at home for the first time (after making at the cottage a zillion times) and took out my city mixer. Oh so wrong. The cookies did not turn out the same as when stirred by my "husband mixer." My electric mixer overworks the dough. And my city gas oven was too hot, baking them crisp on the edges and raw in the middle. My electric cottage oven worked so much better.  Turn hot ovens down to 350! Good luck!

----------------------------------------------------------

Original: This is a wonderful recipe and I made it almost exactly as directed. The only thing I added was a tbsp of molasses to deepen the flavor. I made them with just a spoon and a bowl because I was at the cottage so no risk of overbeating. My flour was not too dry and I used baking soda, not to be confused with baking powder that the recipe does not include but many reviewers used. They came out as promised, toasty on the outside and chewy on the inside. They are a flat cookie, not a round cakey one, but I like that. Excellent recipe. A keeper! My husband hoovered them down pretty fast, musing that they were healthy enough to eat with his morning coffee. Uh huh, any excuse would have done.

text:
I love this recipe.  I did make a few changes.  I skipped the white sugar altogether and used a rounded 3/4 cup of dark brown sugar.  I used extra cinnamon and approx 1/2 cup more raisins. I soaked my raisins as I usually do.   I added 1 cup chopped walnuts and 1 rounded 1/2 cup of  flaked coconut.   Because I had added extra ingredients I decided to add approx 1 tbsp of olive oil after I had creamed my sugar, butter and added the eggs.  The cookies turned out great and were a big hit with my family.

text:
Great recipe! I followed all the ingredient proportions except cinnamon (I put in 1 tsp. instead). Following some advice from others, I soaked the raisins in hot water as I was preparing everything. I had to put the butter and sugar mix in my freezer for like 5 minutes because I had it set on my stove top and my inductor cooker turned out so it melted a little bit of the butter and sugar mix! I freaked out a bit because I was scared that my recipe was all ruined and would be runny but that didn't end up being the case. I also put the cookie mix (without the raisins and oatmeal) in the freezer for about 30 minutes.I cooked it in a toaster oven and the timing was right, which was about 8 minutes. My toaster oven's temperature is always not accurate. The oven temperature is actually lower than what it says on the oven but at the same time, it works! Maybe it's because it's so small and the contact is close to the coils. However, I think 190 degrees C on my toaster oven was too high so I had to lower it to 180 degrees C. The cookies turned out great! I would definitely keep this recipe.

Five stars - after these tweaks. I halved the recipe - so don't know if that will affect the success of my tweaks should you choose to try them. First, I substituted whole-wheat flour for white. I used just 1 quarter cup of white and brown sugar, omitting the extra table spoons. I added 1/4 teaspoon cloves and, for the heck of it, 1 table spoon organic chia seeds. I used 1/2 cup raisons and, well of course, added 1/2 cup bitter-sweet chocolate chips. I baked 8 minutes at 375, then turned the sheet around in the oven and baked another 9  to 10, depending on how they looked. Oh. My. Gosh. Mmmmmm

text:
Several changes because I had only one egg and wanted it extra healthy. For missing egg I used abt 3 tsp chia seed soaked in 2 Tb warm water and dded 1/2 tsp baking powder. Also subbed coconut oil for butter (it was solid). Soaked yellow raisins in warm water 15 minutes then drained. Added more spices-cardamon, nutmeg, allspice, ground ginger. Came out perfect and hardy. I will freeze and  use for picky teenager's breakfast snack.

text:
I just made these, and love them! I have a 5 month old son and I was able to make these while wearing him in his baby wrap. The recipe was simple and easy, which is always a plus! I read the reviews before making them, and I did what one commenter said to do and added an extra 1/2 tsp of baking soda, and an extra 1/2 cup of flour. They rose like they were suppose to and weren't flat at all when I did that. I sprinkled the top before baking with a just a little bit of extra cinnamon, and everyone has loved them so far! This recipe made me 32 cookies that were ranging in size from medium to large! 
I would definitely make these again, I'm glad I found a recipe for my favorite cookie.

My first time to try this recipe I added chopped cashews instead of raisins. I've been doing so ever since and it was perfect for me! city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm looking for a good Oatmeal cookie. I always read the reviews for a little insight. I don't like to waste my time or money making something that isn't what i expect. I made the cookies with the following changes based on the reviews. Added 1/4c flour, 1/2 teaspoon baking powder, 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg and reduced white sugar to 1/2 cup. Baked at 350 for 10 min convection oven. They turned out great. They had a nice rise, crisp on the outside and soft inside. No issues with sticking. Thank you to the original submitter and all the reviewers.

country:
None
text:
These are very good, but need a few adjustments.  I don't think they are overly sweet.  The sweetness is just right.  They are kind of flat tasting though.  I made a 1/2 recipe, did a sample cookie first.  Then added about 1/8 t. more salt and 1/8 t. more baking soda.  If baking these in high humidity, I'd add 2 T more flour.  I made them in the dead of winter with very low humidity and they were the perfect consistency.

The original recipe is lovely home style goodness. I wanted something a little more refined so:

I adjusted  by replacing rolled with steel cut oats. Replaced the cinnamon with tsp. ground cardamon and tsp minced orange zest. Replaced the all purpose flour with a cup of white bread flour and a quarter cup of rye flour.

text:
I made two batches from this recipe. The first batch was made per the recipe. Wet ingredients were mixed with a hand mixer, dry ingredients were mixed by hand. They came out too crunchy and a bit bland for my liking. For the second batch, I added 1/2 cup applesauce, extra Cinnamon, a dash of Cloves and Allspice. These changes made the cookies much better, moister and more flavorful.

text:
Easy & delicious recipe that took virtually no time at all to make. For a healthier alternative, I substituted the butter for applesauce and reduced the sugar slightly to compensate for the extra sweetness. I also used all organic ingredients and an oil spray to grease my stainless steel cookie sheet. Turned out perfectly, slightly crunchy on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside! The only slight modification I will make next time is to soak the raisins as others have mentioned and possibly add some chocolate chips! 2 thumbs up!!!

I think Quick Cook oats may work better and next time we'll also soak the raisins in boiling water and use parchment paper on the pans - they were really hard to get off the pans without parchment paper.  I'd try a totally different recipe next time.  Very disappointing.

I even added 1/4 c flour and 1/2 tsp baking powder per another reviewer's suggestion... I might try it again sometime adding more flour since we are at 4,000 feet above sea level.  Or I might just move on to another recipe.

text:
Look no further for a soft good oatmeal cookie. My cookie never spread or anything but then I did not use a mixer I just used a wooden spoon to mix everything and for my family I added ground cloves and a little more cinnamon for extra flavor. The total cooking time was 8 minutes and they were perfect and still chewy the next day. I find the recipe versatile because I also added chocolate chips and walnuts but even without them this cookie is a winner. Thanks for sharing.

text:
I do love these cookies but I only gave it 4 stars because I found I had to tweak it quite a bit:
Because I found the batter a bit thin I added and extra 1/4 cup of flour. I used an electric mixer until about half of the flour was in then added the remaining ingredients with a wooden spoon. I do this everytime and they always come put perfect.
And for personal preference I add an extra 1/4 teaspoon of cinnamon and 1/4 teaspoon of each cloves and allspice.

text:
For everyone who had trouble with it turning out flat and crunchy, I recommend that they keep it in the oven for 10-12 minutes and even if it looks a little bit soggy, to take it out. It will harden if you give it 10 minutes to cool but the inside will be chewy. 

I loved it and it was very easy to make. A little bit too much sugar, but that can easily be changed.

text:
Luckily I read some of the reviews about the thinness/running....my first batch was way too thin.  I added less than 1/4 cup (maybe an 1/8) of flour to the remaining batter, dropped the oven temp to 350 and baked for closer to 10-14 mins (depending on size).  I did not soak the raisins as others suggested.  The slight modifications worked wonders and the cookies were delicious.  Everyone loved them.  Yummy and chewy.

text:
Ok so I give this one 4 stars after I tweaked it. I used 1 cup of whole wheat flour, 3/4 c. unbleached flour, 1/2 c. each white and brown sugar and 1/4 unprocessed bran, I omitted the salt as I do in all my cooking and substituted with 1/4 tsp. baking powder. I had no problem getting them off the cookie sheet as I use parchment paper. Great healthy cookie! Yum

text:
I am glad I doubled this recipe because these cookies were loved by everyone! I made a few adjustments since I was working with what I had on hand. I used half Country Crock butter substitute and half Crisco. I also used half of the raisins, since it seemed like a lot. Next time I will use the correct amount. I made sure to cool the dough before spooning onto aluminum foil lined pan. My cookies were not flat like some people described although I had to cook them a little longer than the time listed. Since I lost my own cookie recipe, I am adopting yours.

text:
My son's girlfriend wanted Oatmeal Raisin cookies, and I could not find my old recipe.  I made these as directed.  They came out wonderful.  I used my old air-bake cookie sheets ungreased and there was no sticking, no running, etc etc.  The raisins were nice and chewy like they should be and the cookies were soft even after a few days.  I used my kitchen aid mixer and the consistency of the dough was perfect.  I only baked the cookies for 8 minutes as my electric oven tends to run a little hot.  Came back to save the recipe to my box and will most definitely make again.

I did only use a 1/2 cup of white sugar and used 3 cups of oatmeal and used 1 teaspoon of cinnamon, because we both love it, next time I will use a little more!   Also I halved the batter and added raisins to one half, and quartered the other 1/2= 1/4 with butterscotch chips and the other rest with the chips and walnuts....mmmmmmmm

text:
Attention all cookie lovers out there:  If you are frustrated with cookies sticking to the pan, you really need to invest in a Silpat silicone baking mat.  I don't know how I lived without it!  Cookies slide right off the mat.  Also indispensable is a melon baller for scooping the cookie dough onto the mat, makes neat, uniform cookies.  I loved this recipe and will definitely be making these cookies again.

None
text:
In an attempt to be cutting out white flour and white sugar from my baking this is how I altered these cookies.  I used Turbinado Raw  sugar in place of the white sugar... it worked well but I think that if I grind it in a coffee grinder or mortar and pestle it would be a bit smoother.  I also mixed my flour 1/4c barley flour, 1/2 cup whole wheat, 1/2 white.   I used semi- sweet chocolate chips however because I had no more raisins in the house. Perhaps I should have checked that before trying to make oatmeal raisin cookies.

Anyhow, the cookies turned out fantastic, they weren't runny at all, perhaps because of using the heavier flour and they taste amazing, could even use a little less sugar next time.

text:
My version turned out pretty well. Made the cinnamon a round, whole number at 1 teaspoon. Added 1 tsp allspice. Took out 1/2c of the white sugar, and also hydrated the raisins as I prepared the dough. I ran out of baking soda, so I put in baking powder instead.
I hand-mixed as suggested by the other reviewers and although a little tired out was pleased at the consistency. Baked at 180 degrees Celsius so I ended up cooking it twice as long as indicated. Chewy, yummy and flavorful :)

Display Name:
Lucie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My sister and I wanted to be nice and cook a batch of oatmeal raisin cookies for her roommates to say thankyou (as I am imposing myself on everyone for two nights).
I consider myself an alright cook and had a bad feeling about the extremely runny consistency of the cookie mixture. My sister, on the other hand who believes in following things by the book, assured me to just follow the recipe and go ahead and bake them as they were. 
What a disaster. Firstly they were ridiculously runny and became flat like giant pancakes. We had to chisel them off the non stick, heavily greased baking tray ( by the way what kind of a cookie recipe needs you to grease the tray??). Even though golden brown and cooked for the advised time, they were cakey and soft. I like chewy cookies, but not cakey soft cookies, weirdest consistency raw and baked. This mixture DEFINITELY does not need 2 eggs,  unless you want to make oatmeal raisin muffins or cake. 
If you are going to bake these, don't add the second egg and use a lot more flour or find any other recipe than this. 
However, good flavour.

text:
I lost the tried and true cookie book I've used for 21+ years, so decided to make these based on the high ratings. Mine were bland and dry, and did not flatten at all. They were hard, dull little dry lumps. They need more cinnamon, butter, sugar, and raisins, and less flour. I added chocolate chips and craisins to salvage the last bit of dough and these were much better. Time to buy another cookie book, if I can find the right one.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well, I was nervous after reading the reviews, but was the better for it. I made these for my 3 year old who has dairy allergies. I never made cookies for her before and am not the best cookie baker, but these came out GREAT. I used smart balance light butter (which is surprisingly dairy-free and recommended for vegans). In replace of the eggs I used "egg replacement" (which can be purchased at whole foods). When I finished making the batter, I was afraid it was a little loose, so like the some of the other reviewers I added a little flour (roughly about 1/4 cup). After I added the oats, the batter thickened again. I baked them with my fingers crossed and my goodness they came out perfect!! Even my husband, who is not to crazy about sweets, loved them. But best of all my sweet little angle (who helped mom make them) love them as well. Thanks for sharing this recipe and thanks for reviews!

None
text:
These turned out quite good but I made a lot of changes after reading other reviews hence the four star. Here's what I did - reduced fat by cutting butter to 1/2 cup and added 1/4 cup oil, upped the flour to 1.5cups (50% whole wheat and 50% all purpose flour), reduced sugar to 1/2 cup each. Added 1.5tsp of baking pwd and 1/2 tsp baking pwd. I also added a cup of milk (because the mixture was too tight) and added chocolate chips.

text:
I found these cookies to be just wonderful!  I followed a few of the recommendations from the other reviews and they turned out perfect.  I used a sil-pat(silicone baking sheet) on my pan so they wouldn't stick and I rolled them into balls before placing them on the sil-pat.  They didn't get flat at all instead they stayed nice and fluffy.  I also increased the cinnamon to a full teaspoon and decreased the white sugar to just half a cup and the raisins really do give it just the right amount of sweetness.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was similar to a recipe I used to use, but have since lost sadly.  I added about a cup of extra oats, and another half cup of flour as I thought the dough seemed a bit runny.  I added an additional half cup of raisins, and I also soaked my raisins in boiling water for about a half hour before I started baking, it mad the raisins plump and moist.  I also used about a tablespoon more butter, and an extra half cup of brown sugar.  I dropped them a tablespoon at a time on to the pan and they came out nice and moist and did not spread at all.  The next time I make them I will definitely be adding more raisins!

text:
Wonderful!!  I did make changes.  1/4 additional cup of flour. 1/4 less cup of white sugar. 2 tsp of Baking Powder to replace the baking soda. 1 tsp cinnamon.  This recipe was so thick I worried that the cookies would be dry, but they weren't.  So delicious.  I can't help wondering if the problems mentioned by others about "spreading too thin" have to do with calling for baking soda instead of baking powder, which I used.  Anyway, I probably won't add the extra four next time!

Hard to review on original recipe because I made some changes...1 cup brown sugar & 1/2 cup white sugar.  1/2 tsp cinnamon & 1/2 tsp nutmeg.  2 cups large flake oats & 1/2 cup quick oats. text:
I used this recipe more for a base for my own. I modified and use about 3 tbls of vanilla, also increased cinnamon to double that which it calls for. I did not have the full 2 3/4 cups of oats (unexpectedly)  so I added some wheat bran about 1/2 cup and also some milled flax seed. They turned out VERY soft and airy. They went over well, my family was eating them right off the pan as soon as they came out.  They did turn out more like a cross between muffin and cookie. I also put my raisins in the microwave with about 1/2 cup of water for about 4 mins, they became soft and plump and were delicious in the mookie (muffin/cookie).

country:

text:
Great recipe! I don't know why everyone else had so much trouble! I basically followed it to the letter--though I'm not the biggest fan of perfect measurements. I think I used a tad bit more brown sugar than called for, definitely more cinnamon, and a few more raisins (just cause i love my raisins). They turned out GORGEOUS and even. No running into each other or anything.   Only problem was that I left them in for 15 minutes, and suspect they could have even gone longer! Maybe it's because I live below sea level (New Orleans) at a super-low elevation...but I think that only works the other way around. Anyway, they're beautiful cookies.  I used Quaker 1-minute oats and had no problem. You can totally use instant oats in this recipe.

userID:
2744266
Display Name:
linds
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/160804.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like most posters, I made a few tweeks to this recipe. Because the dough was thin, and taking the advise of previous posts, I added 1/4 cup of flour. I also upped the cinnamon to 1 1/4 teaspoons and added 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg and 1/4 teaspoon ground cloves for added flavor. I soaked the raisins in Rum and increased the amount to 1 3/4 cups.  The first batch were thin cookies, crispy on the edges and soft in the middle. They were uneven shapped and wonkey. So, I lowered the oven to 350.  The remaining batches turned out soft moist and round on the edges.  I did yield aprox 4 dozen. I only give 5 stars to recipes that need no tweeking. These cookies did turn out great. However, there was added work needed to get them that way! Happy Baking!!

5

text:
I used 1 1/2 cups of flour and 1.5 tsp of baking soda plus I did the raisin soak and added 1/4 cup of coconut to give it some strength. I also ended up accidentally halfway melting the butter in the microwave but it didn't hurt the recipe. I chose to use a rubber spatula to fold the flour mixture in 3 stages and to mix the oats and raisins into the dough. It saved me overworking the dough and you know what? This recipe with it's alterations proved to work perfectly! Yum!

text:
These cookies came out wonderfully! I'm sorry the last reviewer had a difficult time with them, but I do not think it's the fault of the recipe. I am an experiences baker as well and because I read the previous reviews, I knew to add the additional 1/4 cup flour. I also prefer a spicier cookie, and so added extra cinnamon and a bit of ginger. Yum! I baked these on a stoneware baking sheet, a silpat, and a cookie sheet. They came out best on the stoneware, but only marginally, as the cookies baked on the silpat as well as cookie sheet were also very good. Enjoy!

country:
None
text:
These cookies are AMAZING!  I read the reviews and went with the extra 1/4 cup of flour.  I also decided to soak the raisins in warm water before adding to the mix.  This made them just melt right into the cookie.  I also toyed with this recipe by baking first on a round baking stone, then on a cookie sheet with parchment paper.  The parchment paper tended to make them a bit dry, but the baking stone made them absolutely perfect!  I just had to bake them longer for about 13-15 minutes.  I love my oatmeal cookies sweet and chewy and these were definitely my favorite so far!!

Unlike some of the negative reviews I read that the cookies "ran" or were "greasy" or "flat disks", not at all, I thought they were excellent. I was looking for a soft, chewy, flat oatmeal cookie better than the recipe I had been using and these were delicious. text:
These cookies are one of my favorites! I've had some of my creations sit in the kitchen untouched, but these cookies are gone by morning. I've substituted the raisins for cranberries and chocolate and both batches turned great. Next time I do chocolate chip, though, I'm not going to use an entire cup of chips as it turned out to be a little too rich. 3/4 cup might work better. I've used baking sheets, but found that there's enough butter in the cookies to use the recommended ungreased cooking sheet. This recipe is definitely a keeper.

region:

country:

text:
These were yummy! I cut the white and brown sugar to 1/2 c. and the cookies tasted perfect- not too sweet, not too bland! I love spices so I increased the cinnamon to 1 tsp and added 1/4 tsp nutmeg as well. I also reduced the oven temp. to 350, which was perfect for 8-10 minutes of baking. I flattened the cookies 4 minutes into baking with a spatula to make them look a little better. After I tried a cookie I realized something was missing- walnuts! A cup of chopped walnuts would make this recipe even better.

text:
I made this exactly to the recipe. My cookies came out flat, thin, crispy on the edges, slightly chewy, very buttery. This was exactly what I wanted, I like this better than a cakey cookie. One thing that helped was baking on parchment paper so they could really form up and cool thoroughly without disturbing them. I just pulled the whole sheet of parchement paper off the sheet and set it on a wire rack to cool. 

Yummy! They didn't last long!

text:
I think this is a pretty good recipe.  For those in the UK who use gas, I baked mine at gas mark 5 for anywhere between 7-10 minutes.  My first batch was a bit pale looking and fell apart when I tried to remove them.  The next batch I baked almost 10 mins (peeking at them at 5 mins) and they were much better.  I let mine get to a golden brown, instead of just brown around the edges.  I'm not much of a baker and this was easy and pretty much hassle free.

text:
The flavor is fantastic, but my cookies came out very flat even after taking special care not to overwork the batter.  I had to add a couple minutes to the baking time because at ten minutes they were still very mushy.  Leaving them in for 12 minutes gave me a very moist, chewy cookie that fell apart easily.  Leaving them in for 14 minutes gave me a pancake-flat, crunchy version.  Either way, they taste very very good and both the chewy and crunchy versions got rave reviews at my house.

text:
Mmmm - these cookies are good!  I rated them 4 stars because the next time I make them (and there will be a next time), I will reduce the amount of white sugar to 1/2 cup (we found them a bit too sweet) and increase the raisins by an additional 1/4 - 1/2 cup.  The only change I made to the recipe was to soak the raisins in the egg and vanilla for an hour or so...this plumps the raisins up and makes them nice and soft (yet still chewy).

These are very addictive and tasty oatmeal cookies and the first we've ever made at home! My daughter and her friends made them for her little End-of-School party. Instead of vanilla extract, they used just some vanilla beans and it was still tasty. They also added some pumpkin pie spice which contains cinnamon, nutmeg, and other spices. We used light margarine because we had no butter so it might of made it healthier. They smelled so good when they came out but the girls made a huge deformed cookie instead of individual. The edges of the big cookie were crispy but the rest were chewy and cake-like. Delicious! Will make again.
